Q - Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
And, Dave, talk a little bit about the announcements that you just made today. I believe there was a Board meeting and some of the cash return metrics just got updated, not the targets but what you're actually approved to do. So, talk about the dividend and the buyback.
Dave Pahl
Sure. Yes. So -- thanks first of all for having us, Ross. We appreciate it.
We just recently announced that we've both increased our divided, as well as authorized an additional $7.5 billion for share repurchases. We've had a consistent increased dividend, as you've seen us do, over the past 12 years. And on the buyback standpoint, the $7.5 billion is a figure that we've done in the past. We've done between 7-1/2, one other time we did 7-1/2, we've done $5 billion as well, and really is just reloading on the authorization. So, no change in our commitment to return 100% of our free cash flow to investors. You've seen us do that through dividends as well as the steady repurchases of shares.
I'll just maybe point out that our share count has been reduced through those repurchases since the beginning of 2005 by 40%.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
So if you put this together, I think that it's going to get you just over, what, about 3% dividend yield at the current rate?
Dave Pahl
I think that's about right.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Somewhere in that range.
How do you guys judge the balance between those two, between the dividend and the share repurchase? You do great on both of them obviously, but how do you prioritize one versus the other?
Dave Pahl
Yes. So, how we think about that is we take the previous four years' free cash flow, we take half of that number and use that as the target for the dividend increase. What that has translated to is about 40% to 45% of our free cash flow going to dividend and about 60%. So if you're in an environment where you're continuously increasing free cash flow, you'll be a little bit ahead of that 50% mark.
So we think that that offers flexibility for us to have a dividend increase if we entered into a period of prolonged economic weakness, we could still have the judgment ability to still increase the dividend even in that environment.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Is the 12% increase [inaudible] so I haven't been able to check it, versus prior increases, how was the 12% chosen?
Dave Pahl
It was chosen -- with that framework, yeah.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Okay.
Dave Pahl
Going forward. So you can see, if you run the numbers, it's not an absolute number, it's a starting point for us to have that gauge, but it's real close to that road to get us there.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
And what's the - again, the capital allocation, not only cash return to shareholders but also the balance sheet and the amount of leverage that you want to be able to have on the balance sheet -- I know in the past you've talked about the importance of having a pristine credit rating. Talk a little bit about how much leverage TI likes to have on the balance sheet.
Dave Pahl
Well, when we acquired National, we did that primarily -- we did some cash on that deal, but we had -- I think we started with about $6.5 billion of debt, if my memory serves me correctly. And we've been slowly paying that down over time, and obviously our ability to borrow has increased, so we've got some amount of spread between those two numbers.
I think when we acquired National, our belief was we were going to pay that debt back kind of on the schedule as we had set up the debt. But as low interest rates had persisted, we really came to the conclusion and got comfortable with debt being on the balance sheet permanently as long as it makes economic sense.
So what you've seen us do, like this year as an example, we have paid off -- we'll end up paying off about $0.5 billion of debt, and then rolling the balance of the debt forward [inaudible] time [ph]. So that's basically how we're thinking about it.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
And I know it's a moving target depending upon the health of other aspects of the Company, but what sort of debt load do you think you could carry and still have the highest credit rating, which I believe, correct me if I'm wrong, is a priority to maintain that?
Dave Pahl
Yeah. It's a priority to maintain it. If we had something significant happen where we felt like we needed to take up more debt, we would do that. We do it very, very thoughtfully and very carefully. But all things being equal, we don't have plans or want to change that.
And that's part of the reason why you see us slowly working down that debt over time. Again we're comfortable having it, but, you know, we just like to open up that capacity over time; that gives us more strategic options at some point in the future.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
To the extent it's possible or -- possible to answer, willing to answer, $4 billion roughly is what you have in I believe gross debt right now?
Dave Pahl
Three, yeah, a little --
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
A little under four. Right. What amount do you think, you know, could you triple that size, double that size, that would still keep you in the target range?
Dave Pahl
Yeah. Not a number we'd want to give out, but again we've had I think 6-1/2 on the balance sheet at one point, so.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Right.
Dave Pahl
Yeah. It's a number higher than that today.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Right. So why don't we just stick with the whole cash allocation side of the equation? What's your opinion on the M&A that's going on in the space? It hasn't -- well, I guess it depends somewhat how you define the analog market, but it hasn't hit the big four analog players yet. You were probably the last one to do a big analog deal with National Semi. Talk a little bit about TI's approach to M&A and the potential involvement going forward?
Dave Pahl
Yeah. So our approach really hasn't changed. And, you know, we basically have two lenses that we would look at any potential acquisition, with the first is a strategic one. And there we would look for an analog company and we'd want to find a company that has a very diverse set of customers, diverse set of products, and products that are finding long-lived positions in the marketplace, products that are differentiated, a.k.a. they have good margins, and having a company that's continuing to put out those high-quality products. So you don't want to buy something that, you know, was good ten years ago and still not producing good-quality parts today.
And if you think of National, they're probably a great test keys for that, right? You can go through the check list there and check off each of those as you walk through. So that's, you know, some of the things that we look for from a strategic standpoint.
If you look from a financial standpoint, we'll look at a lot of different financial metrics. You know, a couple of them that would come to the top would be, can we achieve our cost-to-capital in a three to four-year time period? You know, how does that investment look versus buying back our own shares? And what's the free cash flow return off of that investment?
I think with our stock price, I didn't do the math today, but I think we're above 7% free cash flow yield. There was a point not too far long ago that we're just about 8% on that target.
So, those are some of the things that we'll look at. Nothing is ever absolute on each of those metrics, but those are the things that go into consideration.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
And I know you've said this in the past so this is nothing new, make sure to clarify that upfront, but why prioritize analog over embedded? You know, embedded is another strategic focus area for the Company, but you've repeatedly said, I think even last year up here Kevin said that analog is the priority, not embedded.
Dave Pahl
Right.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Why one versus the other?
Dave Pahl
Yeah. It really comes down to that those businesses, they're both good-quality businesses, as you talked about, but they make their money very differently. And what I mean by that is, is that if you have a very unique analog product and you get 10 customers or 100 customers that value that uniqueness, they could buy that product for, you know, five years, 10 years, 20 years, and there's economic benefit for that uniqueness.
In embedded, having a unique architecture or having a bunch of architectures doesn't help you running a really good embedded business. You want to have as few of architectures as possible, as many customers, and as much revenue over those. So, just buying other companies and sticking together more architectures, bigger is not better in that case.
So we've got lots of examples or several examples of companies that were stuck together that have lots of architectures that, you know, the number one supplier, as an example, there's lots of architectures that they struggle financially, so.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
So the scalability is much better in the analog side is what it comes down to, on the architectures.
One other aspect of the strategic focus that I would think would come in when looking at deals if you guys have a very large fab footprint.
Dave Pahl
Yup.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
You've been opportunistic in adding to that, the leader with 300 millimeter capacity, etcetera. Does it go into the equation of somebody who could help fill those fabs? You're not just going for scale for volume's sake along, but all else being equal, if somebody is using a bunch of 300 millimeter wafers at X, Y, Z foundry, I would think it'd be all the better to build them internally?
Dave Pahl
Yes. So the simple answer is no. But let me back up and explain why. Let me start with, you know, we've put in place over the last few years an $8 billion 300-millimeter plant. And so last year we built about $2 billion of analog product on 300 millimeter. And the reason why we like 300 millimeters, it gives us a 40% cost advantage when we do that. So we gave an example of how that runs through the P&L, and the silicon costs at 40% less, it's about half of the cost of the total product. So, in that example that we gave, for a product that we sold for a dollar and was at 60% margin, that same product built on 300-millimeter gives us 68% gross profit. So, economically there's a lot of reasons why you'd want to do it.
The reason why the answer is no is that, if you think of the types of companies that we'd be interested and ones that fit that criteria, they by nature have a very diverse customer base. And just trying to move each of the products over to that just takes too long to involve. That isn't the reason to do the acquisition.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
And that's some of the reason, I would assume, that you haven't closed any of the fabs came with -- came with National.
Dave Pahl
That's correct.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Same sort of -- it's easier to redesign things going forward at most than it is to port them over.
Dave Pahl
That's right. Yeah. And we've moved some of the process technologies from National into our factories, so they've released new products. And then our engineers and their engineers -- their engineers have access to our other technologies which they've used, and some of our product groups have used some of their older technologies as well. So we get a benefit in both directions.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
So, since we talked about the 300-millimeter side a little bit, talk about the end-markets that that's most applicable to. Some of the clarification on that math with the gross margin is, you know, it's 40% cost savings, but the dye itself is only half of the cost, and so that kind of gets you to the 20% benefit that you're talking about. That sort of cost-centric area I would think would be best-suited to higher volume end-markets, but -- so, talk about the end-markets that best fit what you're doing in 300-millimeter.
Dave Pahl
Yeah, there -- you know, if you build anything with 40% lower cost, then that market goes to a 40% lower cost. So it really benefits any of the markets that will serve. And in fact, all four of our business units have products running inside of Richardson today. And there's a belief that, jeez, yeah, you've built so many products in each 300-millimeter lot that there's only a few products that would make sense to go there. But in fact we can actually build split lots where we'll have in a 24-wafer manufacturing lot, theoretically we could have 24 different products running there. Practically we don't do that, but you could, you know, run one wafer and 23 of another type inside of a manufacturing lot. And we can do that because 300-millimeter manufacturing equipment is fully automated. The wafers are not touched once they enter the building, until they go out the other end. Everything is done, you know, through machines handling it and moving it around the fab. So that's why you can build that type of efficiency. You don't see that same type of efficiency in a 200-millimeter fab.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Maybe the last question on the fab footprint, is, some of the competitors, actually I think two out of the three largest competitors are doing increasing amounts of foundry usage, instead of adding their own fabs, or even in some cases they're shutting down fabs, talk a little bit about what you think the trade-off is, where TI is willing to have its own fab footprints, where others are going to foundries, what's the sort of advantage or trade-off you see in making those strategic decisions.
Dave Pahl
Yeah. So, you know, when we look at our strategy of acquiring assets at very low prices and putting in place that capacity, we're able to put that -- we've got $6 billion of open 300-millimeter capacity to grow into, and we're able to grow into it and keep our CapEx at 4% of sales. And that gives us control of our manufacturing process. It allows us to continue to invest and differentiate and process technologies.
If you're moving to a fab, and let's say that you develop a process technology and you're going to run more wafers a year, that's something that's not attractive from a foundry standpoint, but we've got that flexibility to be able to do things like that. And maybe linking back even to your last question, we may have some products, you know, we can shoot down a 90-nanometer on some of the equipment that we've got inside of our fab. Well, you may have products that run at 250, 300-nanometer. So when you're running on that equipment, you can get tighter tolerances and differentiate your products on some of them by running it there.
So we've got a lot of advantages to doing it, and again those assets are going to be -- have useful lives of a decade or 20 or 30 years in some cases. So the return on that investment will be very high. And when you're locked into a foundry for 10,000 products across 70,000 customers, you really, just like the reason why we wouldn't want to move those products, it's really difficult to move them out of those fabs. And you think 10 and 15 years from now, who will have more pricing power between the owner of the fab or the people putting purse on it. Those types of things compel us to want to continue to own our own fabs.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
And again, if any investors have any -- or anybody in the audience have any questions, just raise your hand, we'll get the mic over to you.
Why don't we shift over a little to the end-market side of things? You guys break out things most precisely between analog, embedded and other. But if we went into the end-market way of looking at it, talk a little bit about the growth drivers within the industrial and automotive markets. Those are the two you highlighted as growing fast, as being focal points for the Company going forward. Maybe starting in the industrial side, what are some of the drivers that you see? And how much of that is going to be GDP-dependent, you can do everything you want to do, but [inaudible] up here, and said, yeah, that's still going to be, if GDP is bad, it's going to be hard to grow that segment.
Dave Pahl
Right. Yes. So, you know, I think in industrial, we -- it's pretty obvious, if you just looked around and see where semiconductors are showing up today, that weren't there just a few years ago, and I was reminded on my trip here today, Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, they just redid a parking structure, and you've probably seen this before where you pull in and it'll tell you, you know, by floor how many parking spots they've got available. You pull up to a road and you can look down and there's a light above it that's either green if it's available or red if it's not. And all of that information gets aggregated together. So I don't know if there's $5 of content per parking spot or $25 per spot, but five years ago it was zero.
So I think the general theme is that things are getting smarter and more connected, that's driving growth.
You know, another example that have -- I know, Ross, I've told you, my daughter's a new nurse and she works at Children's Hospital. And if you've ever been in a hospital and you've seen that Pulse Ox that goes on your finger and kind of pinches a little bit and a little uncomfortable, now imagine that on a six-month old child, they don't like that a lot, right? So we've got some new technology that's coming out that's wireless, that's a patch that they can put on the child, and it'll wirelessly communicate that. So I think there's more content in that patch than there is on a mechanic thing that snaps on your finger.
So it's hard to say it's one thing. That's the beauty of that market. It's not just one thing. It's not just one type of application where you can come up with a new architecture. It's not one connectivity standard. It's not one sensor that goes into that. So we're positioned really well to service those types of markets.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
And on the automotive side, you know, there's all the buzz words of ADAS and fully automated driving, etcetera.
Dave Pahl
Yeah. Walk in a showroom, you get excited, right? It's amazing the amount of content that's going in. And last year, automotive was 13% of our revenues, I should say industrials 31%.
The other comment I'd make, just going back to industrial, we've got a little over a dozen sectors that make up industrial, and the largest of which is about 4% of our revenue. So you can tell it's very, very broad-based from that standpoint.
Inside of automotive, we've got five sectors that make up the market for us. The largest is infotainment and cluster displays, next is ADAS or Advanced Driver Assist Systems, then powertrain, which includes electric vehicles and hybrids. After that is safety. And then something we called Body. So, think of signal lights, in-cabin lighting, touch-sensitive buttons to put the windows up and down, and those types of things.
So when we look at growth, year over year automotive for us grew double digits. Those five sectors, all of them grew double digits with the exception of one. And that one grew just rounded down to nine. So, very broad-based growth and we just -- every semiconductor company is seeing opportunity there, but -- and we're translating it into revenue.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Everybody is seeing the growth, as you just said, and it's all content is the answer.
Dave Pahl
Right.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
But investors simultaneously get concerned about it if, you know, fewer high-end cars are being sold into China, what's going to happen to the semiconductor guys that are serving the automotive market. How do you balance the unit side versus the content side?
Dave Pahl
We don't spend a lot of time worried about it. Quite frankly, we just believe that we look five and ten years from now, there's going to be more semiconductors and automotive. Does that mean that that line is going to be straight and up to right every quarter? No, it won't be.
And if I go to a market that has probably worse choppiness [ph], like comms infrastructure, that's down, but it's going to carrier CapEx, it hasn't been down as dramatically as what we've seen revenue there. It'll come back. So that's why we really don't worry about those types of things in the near term and really look longer term at it.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Since you mentioned the comm infrastructure side, remind people what percentage of sales roughly -- or maybe what it was a year ago and what it is now, that, unfortunately the number is --
Dave Pahl
It's much smaller.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Yes.
Dave Pahl
Yeah. So, comms equipment is 16% of our revenue. That area that's getting all the attention is wireless infrastructure was 10% of our revenue. And wireless infrastructure is what's down --
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
So, 10 out of the 16 points.
Dave Pahl
Ten of the 16, yeah. Ten percent of TI revenues --
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Correct.
Dave Pahl
-- is comms infrastructure. And that's down 15%.
It's a good business. We ship both analog and embedded and custom ASIC into that business. We make good money and carrier CapEx has been down 15% from a year ago. So that demand will return. We haven't tried to be public on when we think it'll return. Most of that revenue tends to be on consignment, so we've got very good visibility. But even with that visibility, it can change quickly. So, you know, we do know that it will return and we'll be prepared for it when it does.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Knowing full well that it's only 10% of your business and maybe if you can round up [inaudible] line of sight [ph], 16%, I'll ask the question anyway. On the wireless side, so we feel excited about 4G base stations, LTE rollouts, etcetera, etcetera. It seems like we never got good enough times to warrant the down 50% year over year, and it's not specific to TI --
Dave Pahl
Sure, sure.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
-- companies, it's almost every company is saying the same thing. How come without the party we have such a hangover?
Dave Pahl
Yeah. I think that that market has always been choppy, right? And I'll go back to third quarter to fourth quarter of 2011 we saw our revenues fall 40% sequentially. And we think part of the reason is, is that operators announced that they're getting tenders, they're going to spend x billions of dollars. And they typically give their OEMs or our customers a very short period of time to deliver that product. So they've got to get prepared to be able to ship that product when their customers want it. And that just -- and that's the dynamic that drives those cycles more than anything else.
And, you know, it's -- you look at our revenues overall, this year we'll probably ship 60% 4G and 40% 3G. I think last year was balanced, 50/50. We've got a good position across all the major OEMs. We continue to invest in areas like small cell [ph] as an example. So it's a good market. We'll continue to make lots of money in it, be ready to support higher revenues when our customers need it. And it is what it is, you can't control that part of it.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Is there any aspect of the strategic choices you've made in becoming more of an analogy company less digital, so I would assume some of the custom ASICs might not be as higher priority as they once were, and feel free to correct me if I'm wrong on that, in the standalone DSPs as well, when you move more analog and less digital, if those two are de-prioritized to any extent, do you think there'd be any TI-specific headwinds or you still would have a pop-up, everybody is down 50%, you'll get better than that, but it might not bounce back as much because of logical strategic choices you've made?
Dave Pahl
Yeah. We've even had some people take the opposite side of that and say, hey, you guys called it just right in cutting your OpEx in this area. Neither of those were the case, right? It's --
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
We both got [ph] --
Dave Pahl
-- have to do that just depending on how you want to look at that, you know, same things through a different corner of the box.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Lots of ways to be wrong --
Dave Pahl
That's right. Our belief is that carrier CapEx will slowly decline when you look over the next 10 and 20 years, it's not going to go to zero. We don't believe that there's the same growth in carrier CapEx as what we've seen over the last 20 years. So that doesn't make it a bad market. It just means that you invest differently when the market exists like that.
A lot of this equipment have -- has life of 10, 15 years. And you think about operators are putting equipment out into the marketplace, there's coexistence issues and compatibility issues, fallbacks that they need to worry about. So this isn't a cell phone cycle that's being replaced every nine months. They have very, very long lifecycles to them.
So we're investing at a rate that we think is appropriate. Still it isn't zero. So we plan to be in that market. It's an important market for us.
And again we talked a little bit about spending money on small cells. We'll get some revenue this year in small cells, but we've been investing at least for five years in it. And just like with 4G, we probably started those investments 15 years ago. So if you started about five years ago, you're probably about 10 years too late.
And so again, long -- great market, long cycles. We like that market. We'll continue to invest in it. And we'll work hard to earn that business with our customers.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
So there are two topics that you mentioned, almost in passing but I think are important ones to hit upon. The first was the consignment side. And you mentioned that it gives good visibility. Talk a little bit about the adoption of that, what percentage of the Company is exposed to it. And then on one hand I can see how visibility is better because there's no buffer in between where you're worried about how much inventory is floating around, because you control that and you don't recognize the revenue until they're pulled.
Dave Pahl
Right.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
The flipside of it, say like in the third quarter, it's a backend-loaded quarter, if they all know that the inventory is there waiting for them, it could make things even more backend-weighted because they have the luxury of doing hand-to-mouth. So while on one hand it's more visibility, on the other hand, the orders aren't going to come until the last minute. So, talk about the strategic choices and how much of your business that actually impacts or is delivered that way today.
Dave Pahl
Yes. So, about 60% of our revenue goes through distribution, 60% of that goes through a consignment program today. And if you look at our results, last quarter we ended the quarter with 3-1/2 weeks of inventory at our distributors. That's the lowest number in my career at TI, which is more than 25 years now.
And -- but it's low primarily because of the structural reasons of we're paring [ph] that inventory on our books, you can see that in our inventory numbers. But it's also low because we've been delivering consistently on time and we've had lead times that have been consistent, probably pushing three years now.
And for the reasons, like you say, customers comfortable that they can get product, they don't have to have a big buffer themselves, that's contributing to putting pressure on having less inventory out there. We think that's good, because it gives us better visibility to actually where demand is, at our distributors in particular, we can hold that inventory, and because we control it, we can get it, we can get it to the distributor that may need it or an OEM that needs it, and you don't end up with these large pockets of inventory that end up out there when you don't have that direct control overall.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
So it's a good way to boil down demand to being true demand, because they have no reason to, you know, double-booking and all those sorts of issues. The carrying thoughts [ph] of having the inventory would theoretically be the downside, carrying 110 days instead of you used to do, whatever, was 85 or 90 or something like that.
Dave Pahl
Correct, yes. Right.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Got you.
Dave Pahl
Yeah. And that number today is two thigs. One is that -- is the consignment which is an obvious one of we're carrying on our books versus them, but also we structured how -- restructured how we manage our own inventories to ensure more stable lead times, and ensure higher service levels. So, delivering product when we say that we will.
And part of that is, is that during peak periods of weaker demand, we'll build smaller volume products. So as an example of you have a product that runs 10,000 units a year, it may take a half an hour to set up or tear down a piece of assembly test equipment, so -- and it may take you an hour to run those 10,000 parts. Why don't you let it run for four hours and now you got three years of demand that goes into finished goods? So you got confidence you're going to sell that product over the next five and ten years, why not do that? It's out of the way then, so when you have higher volume, higher demands coming through the factory, you're not setting up and tearing down a lot. As you're doing that, you're able to use your assets more effectively.
So there's a lot of different things that are going into why the numbers were it is. And as we talked about earlier, you know, we're actually, a lot of these things are new, so we're using this year to kind of study what's going on. And we talked about the fact that in February, on our capital management call, it's one of the things that we would -- we'd update.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Right. Why don't we -- and again, if you have any questions in the audience, raise your hand. Let's switch over to the margin side of things. Walk us through the gross margin potential of the Company. It's risen very impressively over the last couple of years. Talk about going forward, how much is utilization driven versus depreciation falling off, albeit with a depreciation falling not being a cash benefit to you, but definitely helping the gross margin side.
Dave Pahl
Yes. So, back in February we tried to articulate why we believed we could increase our free cash flow margin, back into the gross margin, because that's the number that we've given, to operate the Company sustainably at 30%. And we put the caveat around it that we've got to be in good markets, and we're just saying, hey, if the world's not falling apart or something weird is going on, we can operate there consistently.
We just turned in 27% free cash flow margins this past quarter, so we've got 300 basis points of improvement. So a big part of that will be the fact that we will build more products on 300-millimeter going forward, as we fill up that $6 billion of capacity, and we enjoy that 40% lower silicon costs.
The other piece, as you said, that's going to contribute to that, is the fixed cost business, right? So we've got that $6 billion of capacity that's running through the P&L today that, you know, you put more product on it, that will fall through nicely as well. We'll get a benefit as we think secularly industrial automotive will grow faster than other markets, and those products tend to have higher gross margins on them too.
And then the last thing, just mechanically of course, the depreciation and CapEx numbers will converge and come down to around the 4% that we plan to spend on CapEx.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
So, lots of moving parts on not only the gross margin but also the free cash flow side of it.
Dave Pahl
That's right.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
Maybe the last question on my side and the last couple of minutes that we have is on the OpEx side of things. I think one of the biggest changes, at least versus my model in the last couple of years, is your R&D going from 16%, 17% of sales now down to maybe 10 or 9-1/2 or 10. Talk a little bit about the strategic rationale behind getting it that low. And when I've asked in the past at different times how sustainable it is, the answer from yourself, Kevin, Ron, Rich, whomever it may be, the first is, well, we're not actually spending that little on our core areas, we're spending the same amount as our competitors or an appropriate amount. Now it seems like the answer is more of the little to, why don't you ask them why they're spending so much.
So, talk a little bit about how you got it down to that level, because at first approximation that's one of the biggest margin improvements to the free cash flow line out of anything you've done.
Dave Pahl
Yeah. And Ross, you may remember, I think it was a year ago, we actually showed a slide in our capital management where we went back and showed our spend of analog R&D as a percentage of revenue, and you can see that line has whittled around a little bit, I think it was set back to 2006. So, you know, eight years or so of data, where it really hasn't changed. Excuse me [inaudible] sorry.
What changed is we exited wireless and pulled that OpEx off. So in the embedded side, we of course actually increased the amount of money we're spending, and that's impacted the operating margins there. So that spend has been effective, it's translated into share gains. And we've talked a little bit about this before we sat down, we've averaged around 30 to 40 basis points a share gain both in analog as well as in EP.
So it really isn't about just trying to spend more money, it's spending that money effectively and having results from it. And that's what we're trying to do.
Ross Seymore - Deutsche Bank
So at the end of the day, you have no reason to believe it's anything other than sustainable amount --
Dave Pahl
That's correct, yeah. Yeah.
And, you know, and I know we're running short of time, if I put that into kind of how we think about our business overall, we've got four competitive advantages that we're continuing on investing, so -- and those are things that we've covered here of manufacturing and technology that gives us a cost advantage, the breadth of the product portfolio, the reach of our sales channel, and then our long-lived diverse position.
So, really when we think about it is, can we strengthen those four competitive advantages, and building a broad portfolio, if they're not good products, doesn't matter if you do twice as many of them. So, you know, it's really finding the products that customers want that have a differentiated position, and that's what we're focused on.
Ross Seymore
Great. Well, Dave, thank you very much for coming

Texas Instruments, Incorporated. (NASDAQ:TXN) Q2 2015 Earnings Call July 22, 2015  5:30 PM ET
Executives
David Pahl - Director-Investor Relations
Kevin P. March - Senior VP, Chief Financial & Accounting Officer
Analysts
Christopher B. Danely - Citigroup Global Markets, Inc. (Broker)
Harlan L. Sur - JPMorgan Securities LLC
James V. Covello - Goldman Sachs & Co.
John W. Pitzer - Credit Suisse Securities (NYSE:USA) LLC (Broker)
Ross C. Seymore - Deutsche Bank Securities, Inc.
Vivek Arya - Bank of America Merrill Lynch
Christopher Caso - Susquehanna Financial Group LLLP
Ian L. Ing - MKM Partners LLC
Ambrish Srivastava - BMO Capital Markets (United States)
C.J. Muse - Evercore ISI
Timothy M. Arcuri - Cowen & Co. LLC
Operator
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Texas Instruments second quarter 2015 earnings release conference call. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dave Pahl. Please go ahead.
David Pahl - Director-Investor Relations
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our second quarter 2015 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today. For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our website at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the Web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the Web.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the notice regarding forward-looking statements contained in the earnings release published today, as well as TI's most recent SEC filings, for a more complete description.
I'll start with a quick summary. Revenue declined 2% from a year ago, inclusive of notably weak demand in communications equipment and continued strong demand in automotive. In the quarter, we also had about a $45 million negative impact year over year from currency exchange rates, as expected. Even in this environment, our core businesses of Analog and Embedded Processing together grew slightly year over year and comprised 85% of second quarter revenue. Analog delivered its eighth consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth. Earnings per share were $0.65, up $0.03 from a year ago.
With that backdrop, Kevin and I will move on to details of our performance, which we believe continues to be representative of the ongoing strength of TI's business model. In the second quarter, our cash flow from operations was $820 million. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per-share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term. Free cash flow for the trailing-12-month period was $3.6 billion, up 13% from a year ago. Free cash flow margin was 27% of revenue, consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30%. This is a 2 percentage point improvement from the year-ago period, and we believe reflects our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy, the latter of which includes our growing 300-millimeter Analog output and the opportunistic purchases of assets ahead of demand.
We also believe that free cash flow will only be valued if it's returned to shareholders who are productively invested in the business. For the trailing-12-month period, we returned $4.1 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends.
Analog revenue grew 3% from a year ago due to High Volume Analog & Logic. Power Management also grew, Silicon Valley Analog was even, and High Performance Analog declined. As mentioned earlier, this is the eighth consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth for Analog.
Embedded Processing revenue declined 2% from a year ago after 10 consecutive quarters of year-on-year growth. This decline was due to the weakness in wireless infrastructure equipment for the Processor product line. In contrast, the Connectivity and Microcontroller product lines grew.
In our Other segment, revenue declined 17% from a year ago due to custom ASIC products, which are highly concentrated in wireless infrastructure equipment. DLP products also declined, while calculators grew.
In distribution, resales increased 8% from a year ago. Weeks of inventory decreased by 1 week to just above 31/2 weeks, which is a historically low level. We believe this inventory level reflects an environment of good product availability due to healthy TI inventories and stable lead times, which together drive high customer service metrics. It's also important to note that inventory in our distribution channel has decreased over the past few years because we've structurally changed how inventory's managed with our consignment program.
Now I'll provide some insight into our revenue performance by end markets versus a year ago, which in total resulted in the revenue in the bottom half of our range due to more significant softness in communications equipment and incremental softness in industrial. Specifically by end market, automotive had strong growth, with almost all sectors inside this market growing at double-digit rates. Industrial revenue was about flat, in contrast to last quarter's year-over-year growth and was incrementally weaker than we expected. More specifically, there was growth in about half the sectors inside of industrial, but these were offset by declines in others.
Personal electronics grew in total due to one large customer. Outside of this customer, almost every sector inside of personal electronics declined, including PCs, as we expected. Communications equipment declined primarily due to the wireless infrastructure sector, which was down about 50% from a year ago, even weaker than we had expected going into the quarter. And enterprise systems declined due to DLP projectors, as we had expected.
In general, as we look to the third quarter, the strength in demand varies by end markets, but our market in total is expected to be weaker year over year, and our outlook for TI revenue and earnings is consistent with this environment. While we don't control the near-term environment of our markets, we do control the focus on making TI stronger through our approach to manufacturing and technology, the breadth of our product portfolio, the reach of our market channels, and our diverse and long-lived positions. These four attributes taken together are at the core of what makes TI unique and capable of long-term free cash flow growth.
Kevin will now review profitability, capital management, and our outlook.
Kevin P. March - Senior VP, Chief Financial & Accounting Officer
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.88 billion, or 58.2% of revenue. Gross profit was even from the year-ago quarter despite lower revenue, as we benefited from lower manufacturing costs. Gross margin was up 110 basis points.
Moving to operating expenses, combined R&D and SG&A expenses of $790 million were down $31 million from a year ago. The decline reflects the targeted reductions in Embedded Processing and Japan, which have been completed. Acquisition charges were $82 million, almost all of which were the ongoing amortization of intangibles, which is a noncash expense.
Operating profit was $1.01 billion, up 3% from the year-ago quarter. Operating profit margin was 31.3% of revenue, up 150 basis points from a year ago. Operating profit margin for Analog was 35.5%. Operating profit margin for Embedded Processing was 19.6%, almost 5 percentage points higher from the year ago, as we focused our investments for growth and now see the benefit from our plan to better align resources with the opportunities that we are pursuing. Net income in the second quarter was $696 million or $0.65 per share.
Let me now comment on our capital management results, starting with our cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $820 million in the quarter. Inventory days were 126, as we had expected. As our business model has evolved, we continue to evaluate our inventory model. Capital expenditures were $125 million in the quarter. As a reminder, in April, we retired $250 million of debt. In addition, we issued $500 million of five-year debt at a coupon rate of 1.75%. Including the $750 million of debt due in August of this year, we'll have retired $1 billion while having issued $500 million in debt this year. This is consistent with our practice over the past few years. This will leave total debt of $4.125 billion, with a weighted average coupon rate of 2.3%.
On a trailing-12-month basis, cash flow from operations was $4.1 billion, up 14% from the same period a year ago. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $476 million or 4% of revenue. As a reminder, our long-term expectation is for capital expenditures to be about 4% of revenue, which includes the 300-millimeter Analog plan discussed in our February capital management call.
Free cash flow for the past 12 months was $3.61 billion, or 27% of revenue. Free cash flow was 13% higher than a year ago. As we've said, we believe free cash flow growth, especially on a per-share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term and will be valued only if it is returned to shareholders or productively invested in the businesses. And, as we've noted, our intent is to return 100% of our free cash flow, plus any proceeds we receive from the exercise of equity compensation minus net debt retirement.
In the second quarter, we paid $354 million in dividends and repurchased $654 million of our stock for a total return of $1.01 billion. Total cash returned in the past 12 months was $4.08 billion. Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.1% over the past 12 months and by 40% since the beginning of 2005. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our commitment to return excess cash to our shareholders.
Fundamental to our commitment to return cash are our cash management and tax practices. We ended the second quarter with $3.31 billion of cash and short-term investments. TI's U.S. entities own 82% of our cash. Because our cash is largely onshore, it is readily available for a variety of uses, including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock. TI's orders in the quarter were $3.26 billion, down 2% from a year ago.
Turning to our outlook, we expect TI revenue in the range of $3.15 billion to $3.41 billion in the third quarter. As we've said, while strength in demand varies by end markets, our market in total is expected to be weaker year over year in the third quarter than it was in the second. This includes a negative impact of about $40 million due to changes in currency exchange rates. We expect third quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.62 to $0.72.
Acquisition charges, which are a noncash amortization charge, will remain even and hold at about $80 million per quarter until the third quarter of 2019. It will then decline to about $50 million per quarter for two additional years. Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2015 remains about 30%, and this is the tax rate you should use for the third quarter and for the year.
In summary, even in a weaker market environment, such as we saw in the second quarter and expect in the third, our business model, which is built upon the four attributes that Dave mentioned earlier, delivers strong free cash flow. As a reminder, these attributes are our approach to manufacturing and technology, the breadth of our product portfolio, the reach of our market channels, and our diverse and long-lived positions. We believe these attributes, in combination, are unique to TI and they are sustainable, giving us the ability to provide continuing returns to our shareholders.
With that, let me turn it back to Dave.
David Pahl - Director-Investor Relations
Thanks, Kevin. Operator, you can now open up the lines for questions. In order to provide as many of you as possible an opportunity to ask a question, please limit yourself to a single question. After our response, we'll provide you an opportunity for an additional follow-up. Keith?

Yeah. So I'd just be careful with the book-to-bill, and part of the reason why we don't highlight it is because it just applies to a smaller portion of our actual revenues, and that backlog isn't necessarily reflective completely of the demand that we actually see.

Ian L. Ing - MKM Partners LLC
Yes. I think you've done a really good job of highlighting your competitive advantages – broad portfolio, growing into your manufacturing assets. Kevin P. March - Senior VP, Chief Financial & Accounting Officer
Well, there's – been in this for quite a long time, Ian – there's always some market that's in decline and other markets that are actually in a growth phase. So the examples you just offered, if in fact they turn out to be in a secular decline, the offsetting markets for that, the most obvious one is automotive, where we're seeing significant content growth – not just us but many in the industry – seeing significant content growth. And we're still in the very early stages of that content penetrating automobiles. So that's probably a secular growth market that I would suggest would probably add for a decade or more. So that's a great opportunity for the industry in general and for us in particular, because we've been focused on there for a number of years now.
And then there's the broader industrial market, where we're seeing an increasing usage of semiconductors and equipment in those markets that simply were never used before. And as people are using semiconductors in those spaces they're finding new applications and needs for more semiconductors. So while there may be some markets or sectors that could be in secular decline, there are others that are in secular growth. And in general, that leads us to the belief that I commented on earlier in the call, that we think the industry overall will grow at about 2x the global GDP because you've got these kind of underlying changes going on in how semiconductors are being used across our economy.
David Pahl - Director-Investor Relations
Yeah, and I could add, too, that even if you look at a market like PCs that probably over the next 10 years and 20 years will be on a decline like that, we can take two actions. One is we'll spend differently today than we would have spent 10 years and 15 years ago inside of that market. But we can still find opportunities where products will actually live through one product cycle to the next and still have long-lived positions even inside of a market like that. And certainly PCs aren't going away anytime soon. So there's still quite a bit of money that can be made in those markets.

Ambrish Srivastava - BMO Capital Markets (United States)
Okay. That's fair, Kevin. My follow-up is on the factory loadings. Is the right way to also think about, when you're bringing the utilization down, that's mostly on the 200 millimeter, and the 300 millimeter continues to creep up?
Kevin P. March - Senior VP, Chief Financial & Accounting Officer
That's actually not a bad way to think about it, Ambrish, because in fact the way that we are operating the 300-millimeter fab today, our fab, is near full equipped utilization. In other words, we don't have it equipped to full capacity, but to the extent that we have it equipped, we try to keep it quite highly loaded. So the adjustments that we take on loadings generally impact the 200. There may be some impact in 300 as well, but it generally would impact the 200-millimeter factories.
David Pahl - Director-Investor Relations
Yeah. And I'll just add that any product that runs any measurable volume will often source in multiple factories, so it could actually be sourced in a 200-millimeter fab as well as a 300-millimeter fab. Yeah, C.J., as Kevin pointed out, last year 31% of our revenues industrial. The largest sector inside of industrial is factory automation. C.J. Muse - Evercore ISI
Yeah. I do. Well, if you look at our personal electronics market, it was actually up. And it was up because of our exposure in our customer base. This year it's apt to grow less than global GDP. So I think you're just going to have that kind of noise to deal with. I don't think it can be mechanically imposed into a formula with precision.

Timothy M. Arcuri - Cowen & Co. LLC

Texas Instruments (NASDAQ:TXN) Q1 2015 Earnings Conference Call April 22, 2015  5:30 PM ET
Executives
Dave Pahl - IR

Good day. Welcome to the Texas Instruments 1Q 2015 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.
Dave Pahl
Good afternoon and thank you for joining our first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. As usual Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer is with me today. For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our website at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's Web site. A replay will be available through the web.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the notice regarding forward-looking statements contained in the earnings release published today as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description.
Revenue growth of 6% from a year ago was within the range of expectations we provided in January. Automotive and industrial markets were strong as we expected they would be. However revenue was in the bottom half of the range for two reasons. First was weak demand in the last month of the quarter and our personal electronics market, particularly PCs and our communications equipment market, particularly wireless infrastructure. We believe these markets specific issues were due to delay of investments by carriers and capacity upgrades for wireless infrastructure equipment and a weaker than expected refresh cycle for Windows XP. 
The second reason was a steep decline in the currency exchange rate for the Euro relative to the U.S. dollar. The Euro dropped about 10% during the quarter an even though only about 5% of TI's revenues transacted in Euros it was a sharp enough drop that it negatively impacted our revenue by about 20 million more than we had anticipated. 
Even with these pockets of weaknesses our core business of analog and embedded processing turned in their seventh and tenth consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth respectively. Combine these businesses grew 9% and we're 86% of our total revenue. 
Earnings per share were $0.61 reflecting our continued attention to cost controls although the vast majority of our revenue was transacted in U.S. dollars ROE negatively impacted revenue by 20 million which translated to only about 5 million of impact to earnings and therefore cash flow.
 This is due to a partial natural hedged against negative currency fluctuations due to our non U.S. based operations. It's nice to have position to be in this when we have almost 90% of our revenue comes outside of the U.S. But that is a backdrop, Kevin and I will move on with our report on business performance that we believe continues to represent the ongoing strength of TI's business model. 
In the first quarter our cash flow from operations was $609 million. We believe that free cash flow growth especially on a per share basis is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term. Free cash flow for the trailing 12 months period was $3.6 billion, up 17% from a year ago. Free cash flow was 27% of revenue consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30% of revenue. This is a two percentage point improvement from a year ago period and we believe reflects our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy, which includes our growing 300 millimeter output and the opportunistic purchases of assets ahead of demand.
We also believe this free cash flow will be valued only if it’s returned to shareholders or productively invested in the businesses. For the trailing 12 months period we return 4.1 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends. In the first quarter TI revenue grew 6% from a year ago with growth in both analog and embedded processing. Analog revenue grew 11% from a year ago primarily due to power management and high volume analog and logic. Silicon Valley analog and high performance analog also grew. 
As we mentioned earlier this is the seventh quarter of year-over-year growth for analog. Embedded processing revenue grew 2% from a year ago due to micro controllers and connectivity. Processor revenue declined which was impacted by the weakness in wireless infrastructure and again as I mentioned earlier this is the 10th consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth for embedded processing. In our other segment, revenues declined 10% from a year ago primarily due to custom ASIC products which also are heavy in wireless infrastructure as well as DLP products.
In distribution, re-sales increased 11% from a year ago. Weeks of inventory remained at historically low level of just under 4.5 weeks which is a decrease by more than a week from a year ago and is even with the fourth quarter. This level has decreased over the past few years because we have structurally changed how our inventory is managed and the distribution channel with our consignment program.
From an end-market perspective versus a year ago, automotive grew with most factors inside this market growing at double digit rates. Industrial had broad-based growth. Personal electronics grew although growth in PCs was lower than we expected. Communications equipment declined due to wireless infrastructure and enterprise systems grew.
Kevin will now review profitability, capital management and our outlook.
Kevin March
Thanks, Dave and good afternoon everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.82 billion or 57.7% of revenue. Gross profit increased 13% from a year-ago quarter and gross profit was up almost 4 points. Gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased factory load-ins and benefits from our efficient manufacturing strategy as we built more analog chips on 300 millimeter wafers.
Moving to operating expenses, combined R&D and SG&A expense of $777 million were down $68 million from a year ago. The decline primarily reflects the targeted reductions in embedded processing in Japan that were previously announced. As we said that restructuring was essentially complete at the end of last year.
Acquisition charges were $83 million almost all of which were the ongoing amortization of intangibles which is non-cash expense. Operating profit was $958 million or 30.4% of revenue. Operating profit was up 39% from the year-ago quarter. Operating margin for analog was 35.4%. Operating margin for embedded processing was 18.3% more than doubling from a year ago as we executed our restructuring plan to better align resources with the opportunities that we are pursuing as we benefit from our investments for growth. Net income in the first quarter was $656 million or $0.61 per share.
Let me now comment on our capital management results, starting with our cash generation. Flow from operations was $609 million in the quarter. Inventory days were 124 about three days more than planned due to revenue coming in at the bottom half of our expectations. Capital expenditures were $123 million in the quarter. On a trailing 12 months basis, cash flow from operations was $4.04 billion, up 16% from the same period a year ago. Trailing 12 months capital expenditures were $431 million or 3% of revenue. As a reminder, our long term expectation is for capital expenditures to be about 4% of revenue, which includes our $8 billion, 300 millimeter analog plan discussed in our recent capital management call.
Free cash flow for the past 12 months was $3.61 billion or 27% of revenue. Free cash flow was 17% higher than a year ago. As we've said, we believe free cash flow growth especially on a per-share basis is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term and will be valued only if it is returned to shareholders or protectively reinvested in the business. As we've noted our intent is to return 100% of our free cash flow plus any proceeds we receive from exercises of equity compensation, minus net debt retirement.
In the first quarter, TI paid $356 million in dividends and repurchased $670 million of our stock, for a total return of $1.03 billion. Total cash returned in past 12 months was $4.14 billion. Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.2% over the past 12 months and by 39% since the beginning of 2005. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our commitment to return excess cash to our shareholders.
Fundamental to our commitment to return cash are our cash management and tax practices. We ended the first quarter with $3.30 billion of cash in short term investments. TI's U.S. entities owned 82% of our cash. Because our cash is largely onshore, it is readily available for a variety of uses including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock. TI orders in the quarter were $3.21 billion, up 5% from a year ago.
Turning to our outlook, we expect TI revenue in the range of $3.12 billion to $3.38 billion in the second quarter. This represents continuing weakness in our communications equipment and personal electronics markets particularly for wireless infrastructure equipment and PCs respectively. We also do not expect a near term rebound in foreign currency exchange rates. We expect second quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.60 to $0.70. Acquisition charges which are our non-cash amortization charges will remain about even and hold at about $80 million to $85 million per quarter for the next five years. Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2015 remains about 30% and this is the tax rate you should use for the second quarter and for the year.
In summary, we believe that the first quarter demonstrated the strength of TI's business model. While we're not immune to demand in currency changes, their affects are soften by the diversity of our portfolio in our markets.
With that, let me turn it back to Dave.
Dave Pahl

Texas Instruments, Inc. (NASDAQ:TXN) Q4 2014 Earnings Conference Call January 26, 2015  5:30 PM ET

Welcome to the Texas Instruments 4Q '14 and 2014 Year-End Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.
Dave Pahl
Thank you and good afternoon and thank you for joining our fourth quarter and year-end 2014 earnings conference call. As usual Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer is with me today. For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our web at TI.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the web.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the Safe Harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description.
Before I review the quarter, let me provide some information that's important to your calendar. We plan to hold a call on February 4, at 10:00 AM Central time to update our capital management strategy. Similar to what we've done for the last two years on this topic, Kevin March will provide insight into our strategy and also answer some of the most frequently asked questions.
Turning to our earnings update, the fourth quarter marked another quarter of strong progress. Our core businesses of analog and embedded processing grew again with combined revenue up 13% from a year ago. Revenue of $3.27 billion came in at the middle of the expected range that we communicated to you in October. Earnings per share were $0.76 and included a $0.05 benefit for the reinstatement of the federal research tax credit and a $0.02 benefit from gains on sales of assets. Without these two items, our earnings would have been in the middle of our expected range.
In the fourth quarter, our cash flow from operations was $1.3 billion. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per-share basis is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term. Free cash flow for the year was $3.5 billion, up 18% from a year ago. Free cash flow was 27% of revenue consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30%. This is a 3 percentage point improvement from a year-ago period.
We believe this reflects our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy which includes our growing 300 mm output and the opportunistic purchase of assets ahead of demand. We also believe that free cash flow will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business. In 2014, we returned $4.2 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends.
In the fourth quarter, TI revenue grew 8% from a year ago with growth in both analog and embedded processing. Analog revenue grew 14% from a year ago led by Power Management. High Volume Analog and Logic, High Performance Analog and Silicon Valley Analog also grew. This is the 6th quarter in a row of year-over-year growth for analog.
Embedded processing revenue grew 11% from a year ago, due to growth in processors, microcontrollers and connectivity, each of which increased by about the same amount. It is notable that connectivity grew at the fastest rate as we continue to see more products being connected. This is the 9th consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth for embedded processing. In our other segment, revenues declined 14% from a year ago, due to legacy wireless and custom ASIC products.
Turning to distribution, re-sales increased 14% from a year ago, consistent with our combined revenue growth of analog and embedded processing. Weeks of inventory decreased by a week from a year ago to a historically low level of just under 4.5 weeks.
This level has decreased over the past few years because we've structurally changed how our inventory is managed in the distribution channel with our consignment program. This quarter we continue to support more of our distribution sales from consignment inventory and now have about 60% of our distribution revenue on consignment, up about 15 percentage points from a year ago.
With this program, inventory sits on TI's balance sheet and revenue is recognized when our distributors pull products from our consignment inventory that's stored at the distributor's location. We carry higher loads of inventory on TI's balance sheet with this program which has several benefits such as minimizing impact due to changes in distribution channel inventory and giving us greater flexibility to meet customer demand.
Turning to our end markets, in 2014 industrial and automotive combined were 44% of TI's revenue up a couple of percentage points from last year. Specifically, industrial made up 31% of TI's revenue, automotive 13%, personal electronics 29%, communications equipment 17%, enterprise systems 6% and other 4%.
We continue to refine our understanding of our customers' end markets with better tools and software. On our website, we've included the last two years of updated market estimates and we've identified the sectors inside of each of those markets for your reference. Finally, let me make a few observations about the year overall. For 2014, analog and embedded processing revenue grew a combined 12% with analog up 13% and embedded up 12%. We gained market share in both businesses again in 2014.
These two key businesses were 83% of TI's revenue for the year up from 79% in 2013. Because they now make up more of our revenue, they are driving top line growth for the company. TI revenue overall grew 7% in 2014.
Now, Kevin will review profitability, capital management and our outlook.
Kevin March
Thanks, Dave and good afternoon everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.90 billion or 58% of revenue. Gross profit increased 16% from the year-ago quarter. This gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased factory load-ins and an improved product portfolio focused on analog and embedded processing that benefits from our efficient manufacturing strategy.
Moving to operating expenses, combined R&D and SG&A expense of $740 million was down $67 million from a year ago. The decline primarily reflects the targeted reductions in embedded processing and in Japan that were previously announced. That restructuring is now essentially complete and we achieved a little more than our estimated annualized savings.
Acquisition charges were $82 million almost all of which were the ongoing amortization of intangibles and non-cash expense. Restructuring and other charges were a $27 million benefit, due to gains on sales of assets. Operating profit was $1.10 billion or 33.6% of revenue. Operating profit was up 60% from the year-ago quarter. Operating margin for analog was 38.7%. Operating margin for embedded processing was 17.0%, more than doubling from a year ago as we benefit from our investments for growth and as we executed our restructuring plan to better align resources with the opportunities that we are pursuing.
While this is solid progress, we still have work to do in this business. We expect embedded operating margins to continue to increase as our investments in R&D and SG&A will continue to drive top line growth while we hold these expenses flat. Net income in the fourth quarter was $825 million or $0.76 per share. As a reminder, earnings per share included a $0.05 benefit for the reinstatement for the federal research tax credit and a benefit of $0.02 from the gains on sales of assets.
Let me now comment on our capital management results, starting with our cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $1.27 billion in the quarter. Inventory days were 117, slightly above our model range but a number that we are quite comfortable with. It is consistent with a growing portion of our product demands being supported with consignment inventory versus customer-owned inventory.
We believe these consignment arrangements give us better real-time feedback to end market demand that allow us to better manage our factories and maintain short lead times. We expect consignment inventory to continue to increase over the coming years, as distribution becomes a growing portion of our business. We will monitor the appropriateness of our current model of 105 to 115 days of inventory and possibly update this model in the next year or so.
Capital expenditures were $125 million in the quarter. In 2014, cash flow from operations was $3.89 billion, up 15% from the same period a year ago. For the year, capital expenditures were $385 million or 3% of revenue. As a reminder, our long term expectation is for capital expenditures to be about 4% of revenue.
Free cash flow for the year was $3.50 billion or 27% of revenue. Free cash flow was 18% higher than a year ago. As we've said, we believe free cash flow growth especially on a per-share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term and will be valued only if it is returned to shareholders or protectively reinvested in the business. As we've noted our intent is to return 100% of our free cash flow plus any proceeds we receive from exercises of equity compensation, minus net debt retirement.
In the fourth quarter, TI paid $356 million in dividends and repurchased $698 million of our stock, for a total return of $1.05 billion. Total cash returned in 2014 was $4.15 billion which is 3% higher than the prior year. Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.3% over the past 12 months and by 39% since the beginning of 2005. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our commitment to return excess cash to our shareholders.
Fundamental to our commitment to return cash in our cash management, our tax practices. We ended the fourth quarter with $3.54 billion of cash and short term investments. TI's U.S. entities own 82% of our cash because our cash is largely onshore, it is readily available for a variety of uses including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock. TI orders in the quarter were $3.18 billion up 11% from a year ago.
Turning to our outlook, we expect TI revenue in the range of $3.07 billion to $3.33 billion in the first quarter. At the middle of this range, revenue would increase 7% from a year ago. We expect first quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.57 to $0.67. Restructuring charges will be essentially nil. Acquisition charges which are non-cash amortization charges will remain about even and hold at about $80 million to $85 million per quarter for the next five years.
Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2015 is about 30% and this is the tax rate you should use for the first quarter and for the year. The rate is higher than the last year because of an expected increase in profits and does not assume the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit.
In summary, the fourth quarter demonstrates the growing strength of TI's business model. Our strategy is anchored in analog and embedded processing and is bolstered by an efficient manufacturing operation and a broad sales channel. The result is a diverse and long-lived positions in many markets.
We remain intent on excellence in execution, being disciplined in allocating our capital and our firm belief that free cash flow per share is the best long term indicator of shareholder value.
With that, let me turn it back to Dave.
Dave Pahl
Vicki, you can now open the lines up for questions. In order to provide as many of you as possible the opportunity to ask a question, please limit yourself to a single question. After our response we will provide you an opportunity for an additional follow-up. Vicki?

Kevin March
Yes, John, you're exactly right. So going from fourth quarter to first quarter, the best way to model that is to take a look -- really, the last year is a good starting point. We typically are up in the mid-single digits from fourth to first on OpEx and that's because of the absence of the holiday periods that we have in the fourth quarter and the annual startup of pay and benefit increases that we have in first quarter.
This year we might be up just a little bit more than that versus a year ago simply because on higher profitability that we are expecting for the year, we also expect higher variable compensation accruals and so that may take our fourth to first up a little bit higher than what you saw about a year ago.
Dave Pahl
You have a follow-on, John?
John Pitzer

Dave Pahl
Yes. I think when you look year-over-year first of all, it's good to have all four of those businesses contributing to the growth. We also have a very strong product line there too. So I think that those things are helping us to gain share. We've talked about for some time, that it's not one thing inside of a business like analog or embedded processing that allows you to gain share. There is a lot of things that you have to do to be a good analog company and we've got a lot of competitors that fit that category, but we've got other things, like the scale of our -- and reach of our sales force, our presence on the web, our manufacturing footprint, the technology that we bring to bear and the breath of the product portfolio. Kevin March

So that's just another element that helps us be able to win market share versus some of the other competitors that we're up against.

Dave Pahl
Great. You have a follow-on, Harlan?
Harlan Surveillance
Yes. Thank you for that. Your thoughts, directionally on utilization levels here in Q1? So your utilization tends to proceed the quarter you're moving into as to what your expectations are and as the second quarter for the last 3, 4, 5 years now and normally for us is a growth quarter compared to the first quarter, we will adjust our factory loadings accordingly to our expectation to second quarter revenue expectations.

One of the things to keep in mind, when you adjust your faculty loadings, if your quarterly loadings are really for the following quarter's expectations then if you think about the pattern of movement through the quarter you take your loadings. Coming into fourth quarter, our loadings would be dropping coming into the quarter and going into first quarter, our loadings would start to increase during the quarter. And in fact, in analog we've got 18.3% market share and inside of Embedded Processing, we've got around 15 percentage points. So lots of headroom to do that and we've gained probably 30, 40, sometimes more than that in market share on a given year. Texas Instruments Inc. (NASDAQ:TXN) Q3 2014 Results Earnings Conference Call October 20, 2014  5:30 PM ET
Executives
Dave Pahl - VP, Head of Investor Relations
Kevin March - SVP and CFO

John Pitzer - Credit Suisse
Ambrish Srivastava - BMO Capital Markets
