Texas Instruments, Inc. (NASDAQ:TXN) Credit Suisse Technology Conference Call December  3, 2013  2:00 PM ET
Executives
Rich Templeton – Chairman, President and CEO
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Why don’t we go ahead and get started. It’s my pleasure this afternoon to welcome everyone to the Launch Keynote. It’s my distinct pleasure to introduce Rich Templeton, the Chairman, President and CEO of Texas Instruments. We’re going to through a fireside chat, about 40 to 45 minutes in length. We’ll have time to open up to questions to the audience so please don’t be shy. So, Rich, I’ll kind of kick things of.
And clearly over the last several years, you’ve embarked on sort of the transformation of the company out of the digital space focusing on the analog embedded space. Talk a little bit about the rationale behind that strategy, we find it interesting because I spent the last day and half with some of your old competitors and they stand, are doubling down on that business right now. And so, maybe give us some perspective of the rationale behind the strategy, where you thought you would take the company and where have taken it over the two or three years?
Rich Templeton

John, you know when you called a close point. And really when you take the thing back, it’s probably 2006 and ’07, we sat back and we looked at where was, the world going. And we had watched enough things on smartphones and watched some of these vertical on SoC businesses, and we said that that’s not a great place to generate long-term returns.
And the great news is we’ve been building a very significant analog business, we’ve been building a significant embedded business and it was really said at that point, it really makes sense to specify time, analog and embedded, that’s a product statement. And it also is as you recall I think it was in 2007 we said the investment and leading edge CMOS was not going to be a game that paid off. And I think we got that one called right, we got that one called early. And we got those investments re-profiled as well.
So, in many ways those decisions while questioned at the time and painful because it took five or six years to get that revenue rolled off. And it was probably 30% to 40% of the revenue at the time, is why we have the company that we have today over 80% analog and embedded, strong generator of free cash flow and continuing to grow.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Relative to that strategy, it’s not that it’s just light at the end of the tunnel, you’re kind of acting in the end of the tunnel when you look at wireless as a percent of revenue today. And so I guess and the question I always get from investors is going forward, how do you prioritize your resources, and kind of what’s the strategy from here?
Rich Templeton

Yes. So, we’ve talked with investors for several quarters now. But really we started about – it was probably mid-2012, really taking a look. We saw the wireless completion coming to a close. And we said okay, let’s take a look over the next five years, what does a stronger TI look like. And we’re pretty sophisticated, we called it a stronger TI and really took some time writing down what would that next set of changes look like that make the company even better.
And some of them are reasonably logical I think, at least they are to us. Obviously, get to the percent of analog and embedded higher, that’s somewhat mathematical just with where we’re going. But it includes things like increasing the percentage of revenue that we generate from the industrial and the automotive market. It’s got increasing customer diversity, even though our largest customers are down to mid-single digits.
We want to get that diversity even greater, that’s about growing the tail of that curve. More investments and more revenue on the application specific and catalog business as opposed to the custom business, because those will pay better over the long term. So, we really spend some time going through what’s that next set of changes, or the portfolio getting even stronger.
And then really a lot of the work that we were doing underneath that what are the things that will make that happen. So, we have been really busy over the past year working on that next set of changes as opposed to just the drawing some of the decisions maybe five or six years ago.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

In the vein of what’s rewarded is usually repeated. As you kind of come to the end of the journey of divesting the wireless revenue, have you changed the incentive structure inside the company that I would suspect as you were winding that revenue down, revenue growth in other area might have had been a higher priority to try to fill the gap? And if you think about the incentive structure today, has anything dramatically changed now at the end of the wireless journey?
Rich Templeton

Yes. There has not been many ways in the days of public disclosure of the CD&A is pretty accurate for the way we think and the way we operate. And that is really to have a good balanced view across the senior leadership and that’s the same thing we take down inside of relative revenue growth, relative profitability, relative shareholder return. And then of course us subjectively sitting back looking at the leading indicators of how you’re strategically trying to change the company.
So, I think one of the benefits of having a pretty senior team that knows where they want to go, you don’t have to tweak around with the comp system on an annual basis. Because I don’t think that works that well. I think really having people passionate about building a more valuable and a more successful business long-term gets the best results and we’ve been able to do that.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Part of the success of the business model that you’ve kind of taken the cycle out of the business. You’ve focused in on long-duration assets, long duration end-markets, customer diversification. That said you are a student of the industry. And you guys are one of the first of analytics that you were back to put up that unit chart versus trend and were well below trend.
And yet we haven’t caught up. And so, maybe not from a TI perspective but more from an industry perspective, where do you think the growth rate is now for the industry and if it’s slower than past year why?
Rich Templeton

John, I think and you are the best one that commented on it. I think the past three years have been difficult but best for students or people that are disciples of the semiconductor cycles to try to make choices based on that. And I have no idea what all happened over time and in some ways I don’t care that much as you described, okay, as a company if it’s hotter or if it’s cooler, we know how to handle it and we can manage it accordingly. You have a little more to do whether without cycles.
So, I think those have looked very different, you haven’t had those 6 and 8 quarter pronounced runs that you’ve historically had. I don’t know if that continues or if it doesn’t on that front. I do still fundamentally believe that when you look at 20 or 25 year average that having unit growth of 8% or so, which is somewhere north of two times global GDP. I think it still makes sense.
Because I think there is still, if you just look at the end equipment, look at automobiles, look at industrial, there is more electronics in all our lives that’s not changing, that’s not decelerating. And I realize back three or four years that data hasn’t held. But when I just look at the trends around, I would still guess longer term that that’s the right growth rate from an unit point of view, and a dollar point of view. Because I don’t think GDP moves much.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

I know you guys have your Mid-Quarter Update next week, so I’m not going to ask anything near-term. But in the absence of not knowing – is looking at seasonality sort of the best way to try to model this cycle for the industry and for TI?
Rich Templeton

I think you’re watching it even through this last round of earnings calls where people have continued to be surprised by what were estimates out there and where were the companies guiding. I don’t think TI was alone in some of that dialogs.
And I just think where this one is coming back to is I’m not sure that the historical patterns are all that helpful. And so, we would probably just even think differently about the repeating of the numbers, yeah, the math may say that the average is something. I just don’t know how applicable that average has proven to be. And as a result I think you guys are going to have to find a way to set the expectations in a different way.
It’s not something that I worry about that much. And you led to some of that meaning, we’ve got a manufacturing strategy, I think, we made some wise decisions on the capital decisions, three, four years back that let us handle it if the market is hotter or cooler, we can stay pretty disciplined on the operating expenses so you’re not counting on growth absorb things along those lines.
And now the market growth would be what the market growth would be. And our objective internally is to make sure we’re doing better than whatever that market is. And if we keep the team focused on that, good things usually occur.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

On that front, over the last couple of years, independent really of the starting point. You can start to see green sheets of TI growing faster than the peers. And I’m kind of curious what kind of multiple or what kind of upside to industry are you targeting or should we think about because the analog market share changing is like watching paint dry. And it usually doesn’t happen all that quickly. So what kind of targets can you give us on that front?
Rich Templeton

Yes, I’ve been careful with targets instead just look back. And over I think past five or six years, I think we’ve added 30 basis points annually of market share on the analog business. I think embedded is about the same or maybe a little higher.
And in some ways people look at that, say, yes, gees, and that’s without national acquisition adding on top of that so it’s just organic. And like you had excess 30 basis points. Well, 30 basis points each year compounds and starts to really be a significant revenue impact.
And so we’ll keep everybody internally focused on running sales teams and better running product lines better, executing better, the things that we really do control on that. And if we could make that 30 basis points average behind, we certainly would. But so far, we’ve done – we’ve got a reasonably long-term track record of being able to outperform of that.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Returning back to the U.S. analog, you can always question the veracity of the data. But one of the things that really stands out to me in the analog space, which is the space to your point where pricing usually isn’t a big factor. When you map units and pricing, pricing has been horrendous. It’s the worst that we’ve seen I think in the 30-year dataset.
Now, my assumption is, a lot of that I consumer mix growing faster than industrial mix. But what’s interesting, every U.S. Analog guy I talk to says they’re not seeing pricing impression. Everyone except for you is having growth issues. My question to you is how you square the circle on why you think pricing is so bad, and quite frankly if you’re not being a price leader, why shouldn’t you be giving your cost structure?
Rich Templeton

Yeah, I think couple of things in that, John. First is, you somewhat led the witness with the comment of if you look at WSTS and the data, every time you drill a layer deeper, you go to less accuracy I believe. And I think you really got to be careful of just what’s in there, how is it reported. And when I look at things across TI or even look across the industry, I just don’t see a lot of blended average pricing change over a longer period or even a shorter period of time on that front.
And to me, the best way to verify that, which is consistent with the other analog companies that you mentioned is, do you see margin structure changing that much? And the answer to that is, no. Okay, so, I actually believe it remains pretty consistent. And it will tend to go up and down but that up and down is over a three and four year period, it’s not a short-term responsiveness.
So, I don’t think it’s changing that much, I don’t think it will change that much. And to the question of what the TI do, we’ll do what it takes to be successful. I just don’t believe in differentiated products that prices be elastic, variables that really determines the design wind or gaining that business on that front.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Well, not on a apples-to-apples comparable but why not go into end-markets that three or four years ago you might not have the cost structure to be in at the margin profile you want. Given the cost structure you have, why shouldn’t consumer become a bigger portion of your revenue because you could do it more profitably than just about anyone on the planet?
Rich Templeton

Well, I think when we sit back and we look over a five-year period at a stronger company, and you know the benefits as well as anybody on an industrial or an automotive mix improving, it’s going to be longer life cycles of both the products and the design winds, something like the structure that comes out of that.
So, we’re not deemphasizing or participation in personal electronics or consumer, we can participate in it, we can make good money in it, we can do a good job for customers. We would just like the percent of industrial and automotive to be higher on that. Because I think in R&D dollar invested that yields a product that could live for 10 years is going to be a better return than an R&D dollar that produces a chip that was through 12 or 18 months. And that’s what we’ve got to look at.
So, it’s not just industrial and automotive as I commented before, it’s also more investment into application specific or catalog. And if that application specific part or catalog applies well in a tablet or a smartphone, we’ll certainly do great business in those spaces. You’ll find us continue to be significant player on that front.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

When you look at the sub-category, we call IAI which stands for Industrial Auto Infrastructure, the AI it’s pretty easy to see content growth, the auto content growth in electronics, pretty easy to touch and feel. The infrastructure is kind of detail. Can you talk a little bit on the industrial side, which is sort of a catch-hold bucket, I mean, I’ve always seen a company say it’s industrial and they don’t know where it goes.
Rich Templeton

Right.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

But as you think about sort of the growth of content of the industrial, what are the top two or three trends that we should be focused on relative to the TI content growth in that bucket?
Rich Templeton

Yes, so, I think it’s very accurate statement the industrial is kind of everything else. When we spent time over the past year breaking that down, what are we going to do to increase and expand our growth rate even higher? We’ve really broken it down to the next level of sectors and then down to the next level of end-equipments.
And then, really if you go on even the TI website, start to see this TI designs data where we’re putting more technical collateral well, because you’ve got to do a better job supporting those customers. So you’ve got to get specific to do that well.
But to me you’ve got several examples that I think are somewhat obvious, it can range from things like the Nest lab thermostat, the world’s had thermostats for 60, 70 years, they just haven’t had a lot of semiconductors inside of them. And when you want to make and in the case of Nest, when you want to make a great learning and adaptive thermostat, you put semiconductor content in it.
So it’s got processors, it’s got connectivity, it’s got intelligence, it’s got sensors. And now all of a sudden, you don’t need unit growth of the industrial market but you’ve got significantly higher semiconductor content basically replacing electromechanical products. And just go across different leaders and industrial from the Emerson to the Grease in China, to the Schneider’s pick whoever you want.
And go talk to those companies, what are you going to do to make your equipment better or differentiated. And they want to lower the power or they want the service ability higher and that’s all about how do you add intelligence and that means semiconductors. And so be it John Dear putting guidance systems on tractors or air-conditioners that have Wi-Fi so the service companies can know what condenser, compressor to bring out if there is a problem. That’s where you start seeing more semiconductor content.
It’s never going to be the front page of an annual report, it’s never going to be on CNBC or news report but that’s just fine by me. I think it’s going to be actually a pretty important secular trend, because it will be very broad.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Returning back in the analog, historically a very fragmented market. I always think you’re the second largest player, the largest player is this guy called other. Where do you think the ceiling in market share is for a company like TI and if you look at sort of the trends around what customers want, has that changed over the last five years. And so there are views that actually your terminal market share could be a lot higher than you thought it might be five years ago because of serviceability, because of application, because of everything the customers are now demanding?
Rich Templeton

Yes, the simple answer, and it’s not to be believed, it’s just higher. And we’ll probably – I don’t know what it would probably be in 18% or something range depending on where all the data falls in as we continue to incrementally add. And we just need quite a bit of headroom, it’s a $40 billion something market on an annual basis, I think it’s the latest data I saw. And I think we can grow on that.
What I like about where the market is going and take to comments around industrial, they play many of the skills and this is not by accident, it’s by absolute design. Many of the skills we’ve tried to put in place, largest and broadest sales force. So you can get out very deeply across that customer base because no one customer makes up a big percentage, you’ve got to get these and you’ve got to get broad, a broad product portfolio.
So when you’re in that customer solving a problem, you’re not just getting a one ship off of that design, you’re helping them with the controller, the power, and the interface to whatever applications that they’ve got for that. So those pieces have really been put together by design and that’s why when you see additional technical collateral like this TI design work that’s gone now on the web, that’s what customers want, to make the job easy, to make it easy for them to design it in. And they’ll probably use as much of your product that helps them as competitive systems. So that’s the focus. And I think we’ll continue to see that share grow.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

When you look at your operational targets and your revenue targets, grade yourself on the national acquisition?
Rich Templeton

It’s one job that you know the data a lot of investors do, the percentage of larger acquisitions to pay off for anybody with a seller, is the notably in the 20% range. Somebody has also commented that we do one large acquisition every 10 years or so which is probably the right case to try to do those.
We felt very good about the national acquisition, take all the things we’ve talked about to date, industrial focus, great catalog products, great margin structure, talented group of people to develop more new products going out into the future. And by the way we could do it at a price that we can pay back or generate a return on capital.
And so, that thing really has done everything and a little bit more than we had hoped. We have talked, I think it was on the July earnings call, instead of the third year of growing faster than the market, we’ve been able to actually make that happen a year ahead.
As we take a look at the payback and the returns, they look like they’ll be just about on track. Done a little differently as Kevin talked about on one of the earnings calls but that’s encouraging to have an acquisition of that size that almost two years, I guess two years into it is well on track to be able to deliver on that front. So we’re really quite pleased.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Well, there is a lot of different ways to measure the return on investment. But if you look at the cost of the debt that you took on to do in debt, not equity so that you start for instance a lot lower back. Then if you look at the opportunity cost of the cash you gave up, and then you kind of back into what national generated, you can come up with an ROI of north of 20%. That’s pretty healthy ROI. Why not pursue more in organic growth activities?
Rich Templeton

Well, I think that as we’ve talked even with the Capital Management Update last, I think it was last February, we’re open to look at ones that made good sense and it would be very consistent. The industrial and automotive, it will be catalog, it will be analog, long-lived products. Because those are the ones you can actually handle any integration risk and get to the other side of bringing the companies together.
And by the way it’s got to be able to pay back, it’s got the capital within three to four years. So that’s the thing that we just got to pay attention as yes, there is others that meet those early criteria. But if you meet those criteria and the company is well run, it’s also well valued right now and accordingly, because it’s going to be a strong generator of cash.
So I think we’ve just got to be smart, I think generally we really take it very serious to be great stewards in terms of how we deploy capital and the return we generate. And even when we looked at the national deal we pay close attention to how accretive is buying back TI stock. And that’s integration risk free in terms of what that would look like on that front. So we’ll stay pretty disciplined on that.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Switching gears little bit to the embedded side. Often times investors focus solely on the analog and forget to check the login ones, it’s a pretty large business embedded. Every year this conference we do a survey of the investors here and just the investors on Wall Street. And what was interesting is this year, the most investible buzz word for 2014 internet of things.
Rich Templeton

I’d like to go the opposite direction.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

I tongue and cheek sometimes, you can’t spell it without IOT. But that said you do have, it’s very strong IP portfolio in the embedded market including some connectivity assets that you cap. So, do you think about the growth drivers in embedded versus analog, one, which one that grows faster? And when you think about embedded what’s the growth rate there?
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Yeah. I think in general with the business, the embedded guys are probably, I haven’t checked the data lately. If analog has been gaining 30 bps on an annual basis, I think embedded has been a little more than that, solid share gains annual. And I think those guys can both continue to do that.
Obviously, when you look inside embedded, the area that we’ve been heaving up the most, the past three and four years, and it’s for the right logical reasons that there is more customers and more broader applications as the whole microcontroller front. And so a lot of things that we’ve done with low power, higher performance with the 430 and the C2000 family great differentiated peripherals, the things that industrial customers really value and care about, those investments really are yielding and doing the things that we want to see.
We’ve got underneath grades of the connectivity business as you know. And I think it is a fascinating opportunity because you go to my industrial comments, if you want to make things more productive, if you want to make things more serviceable, you need to get them connected up. And it doesn’t just mean wireless LAN, it could be low power RF, it could be lower power Bluetooth or something like that.
And those end up working pretty closely with microcontrollers because there is most likely some processing that’s taking place inside that application. So in general, I think the connectivity thing is a much smaller business, so they don’t have higher growth rates, but microcontroller has to be the real driver growth long-term for grades business.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Same market share question around MCUs, I mean, it does diversify the end market as analog if not more so.
Rich Templeton

Little less but.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

The economics are fairly similar. Where do you think you can drive share over time. And I guess one of the things that I worry about not necessarily worry about because I don’t think they have the business structure to attack this, but some of the connectivity guys in the consumer market are the ones that are spending the most time talking about variables, talking about IOT.
But I struggle because consumer is one customer 100 million units, if you look at that IOT market it’s going to be hundreds of thousands of customers, maybe tens of thousands of units. So where do you think your market share can go on microcontrollers and how well positioned are you if IOT actually becomes the investible theme we all hope it will be?
Rich Templeton

Yeah, I think as you’ve seen on the total embedded number and the microcontroller one looks pretty similar and side of it. Obviously it’s share is lower than our overall embedded shares because we’ve got the benefit of the DSP position that’s historically been a great one for us.
I just think higher, when you’re – I don’t know, where 6% to 7% share, whatever that latest number is like that and it’s been building nicely, we have plenty of room to grow that number higher on that front that’s what the teams are doing.
And on the fact will there be people coming out of consumer markets trying to move into some of those higher profile variables or spaces like that I think the structural barriers will really be pretty solid long term. And this whole idea that our diversity is going to become one of our greatest defense barriers by having no one customer, no one socket or no one end equipment that makes up a high percentage or a significant amount of revenue, it’s no one space to attack.
And to do that, you’ve got to have a business model designed for that in mind. And that is about a large broad sales force, a large broad portfolio applications where you put in technical collateral into all those applications. It’s not finding two big sockets in the four customers per – you’re two big applications and the four customers that make up 100 million bucks. So I think it’s a very different set of DNA that the companies that allude out well will have is my guess.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

I referenced the analog SIA pricing data earlier, I’ll do the same on microcontrollers. Because actually if I look at the data, one of the things that really stands out to me is that microcontrollers is one of the few sub factors other than memory and memory is going through its own cycle dynamics where you’re getting unit growth and ASP recovery.
Now some of that is easy compared from last year but are we starting to see the 32-bit market, maybe some of these new applications actually there on, the overall pricing dynamics than microcontroller?
Rich Templeton

Yes, I would go back, it’s the same one. I don’t think you’ve got a pricing trend down nor up, on a mix weighted apples-for-apples or there is new products come out on that front. It’s just – I’ve not seen that a long time, I don’t see the dynamics changing even with what we observe right now.
And so as a result I don’t think that’s going to correlate, how are we going to find continued good growth with embedded. I think the answer is yes, just because in order to make this equipment more intelligent, to make it more differentiated, that would be about software that would be about microcontrollers that are embedded inside of these systems.
But I think what we end up bringing unique to that is it’s not about just the micro-controller the core, it’s what are the peripherals that you are putting around it that’s what customers really care about. And that analog heritage that we have where you can put great analog peripherals around great low power micro-controllers, couple it up with the power solution or the wireless connection, it’s the capability that none of our competitors in the embedded space have. And I think it’s one we’ll keep taking advantage of.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Is there a targeted mix of end-markets you’d like to see the company at three to five years from now, so if you think of consumer, auto, industrial infrastructure, how should we think about how you think the ideal mix should look?
Rich Templeton

Yes, no, I don’t think there is an ideal mix. I think as we looked at it even on that work on stronger TI, it’s just what a stronger mix look like. And so, we’ll have increasing industrial, increasing automotive, and obviously if those two are going up others will be coming down. I would imagine personal electronics would be a decrease in percentage. But it’s just because we think we can get better returns even on the industrial and auto side. So, I’m not one to have this specific portfolio of what that mix will look like.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Gross margins, do you still have some easy levers relative to underutilization charges you’re taking. Next year your still anniversary low CapEx from the ’09 downturn, but as you go into ’15, you should also have depreciation kind of rolling off. How should we think about, I’m not going to use the word target if you don’t like target, but if market share can just go higher, is the same sort of truth applicable to gross margins and profitability?
Rich Templeton

John, you know this well and it’s probably the best and when I say free cash flow, when you say gross margins, so it’s in many ways I think that’s the best way to help and the best to think about our business. So that is, as we said last February, a target of creating between or generating between 20% and 25% of revenue and converting it into free cash flow, we’re currently running 24% on a trailing 12-month basis. So, we’re pleased with that, it’s been a nice improvement. And I think it reflects a lot of the things that we’ve been talking about over the past five years of changing.
Now that said, you also saw with the third quarter of ’13 results we had said, I forget the exact numbers, it was pushing close to 55% of gross margin, 30 basis points or 40 basis points higher than the previous record. And we did it with I forget it was 8% lower utilization whatever the numbers are that I think.
And I think that just reflects the types of decisions and the types of, since we’ve made better products, increasing mix of 300 mm, fewer 6-inch lines, executing better. And those we’re not done working on, okay. So, we’ll stay very focused, all the things that I’ve talked about today, we keep doing them better, we should be putting better quality products across the company.
The depreciation thing to me is some people are fascinated by us, all just so because it’s already in the 24% free cash flow as a percent of revenue. So whether it’s on the income statement or it’s not going to change when it moves down from one line to the other on that front. But yeah, there is what, 3 basis points or 4 basis points that can move on that line alone but they’re already in the cash flow.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

I want to try to give you a backend of compliment by saying you guys have been better getting out of businesses than getting into businesses. And you stop me very quickly and say that’s not a backend of compliment you’re very proud of that.
As you look at the portfolio today, are there any businesses that you do worry about, and I guess the one that I could ask the most about is, what’s – you guys still have a relatively good presence in the hard-drives from the controller side. I mean, what’s the future of that market for TI?
Rich Templeton

I think in general the answer is, we’re in a really good position if you think about the five or six years that we’ve been working on. And in some ways depending on how long student to TI is the 50 and the 20 years, we’ve not been afraid to take the hard efforts to get into better businesses.
And you and I’ve talked in the past, I just – I really have got to that very simple point like, you work just as hard in good businesses or bad, and the only difference is the good businesses have a lot of return. It’s hard work to do it, and it’s not always popular but I think it really is rewarding.
And so we’ll continue to stay on that but I think most of that heavy lifting is done – which I think is something our investors like to see. There is always going to be portfolio work and portfolio work, and portfolio work could be if an area is not going to grow as fast it ought to have less resource on it. So you could have something like a described business with the preamps and the servo controls.
And if you have an opinion that describes they’re not going to grow that fast then they ought to have less R&D dollars going in at that point in its life. And so, across the portfolio, we’ll always be working on things like that. But to the magnitude that investors observe with the wireless changes, the great news is we’ve got those lines.

Session
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

Any questions from the audience? Very quiet this afternoon. Maybe I can continue. Part of the dividend strategy that a lot of semiconductor companies have embarked upon has been relatively always pleased by investors especially given for the tenure on this. What’s interesting is now it’s cool thought that maybe yield start to go up significantly next year.
If that were to happen, do you think your cash return strategy would change at all, would the uses of cash change, i.e. more buybacks than dividends or quite frankly is there a point in time when we’re actually doing acquisitions with that cash is better than giving it back to the shareholders. How do you think about that?
Rich Templeton

I think we try to lay out and it was really very conscious set of thoughts as we presented last February, pretty formal overview of the capital management strategy. It’s kind of the reason we wrote that down as we do believe that something that you can really embrace for an extended period.
And by the way we’ve got some credibility because what we’ve been doing for the past five or six years looks incredibly like it is well. And so, as we look out as you think about what we’ve designed in analog and embedded business, which carries with it a low capital demand manufacturing structure, which then couples up with a tax strategy that says you’re going to generate significant cash, get it back to where it can be used or returned.
Those things all connect together. And you can’t just do one part of those, okay, in terms of how it works. And as we put that together, I think what we end up offering investors is a very unique generator and return of cash. And so the plans that we’ve got is we’ll continue down that path with about 50% of the trailing 4-year free cash flow towards dividends. And yeah, Kevin views judgment about just what that means, it won’t be absolute precise with the calculator.
And then the balance of that would be used for buyback, lessening debt and the caveat that we put on that one is old decisions that got to be accretive or they’ve got to be smart buyback. And I think we’ve probably shown pretty good discipline over the past, now I guess going on eight, nine years, we’ve really stayed pretty consistent, you saw us in the market even in really kind of tough scary years like 2009. And those buybacks really have been very accretive. We want to be good stewards of that cash and invest it in a way that’s earning its cost to capital I think we’ll be doing that.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

I would say that the risk here with TI is more duration than fundamental. I think at a long enough time-horizon as an investor you’re going to get paid no matter what price you get in on. There is not much of a fundamental risk. The least is – they are harder to find. One that goes will remain it’s not a 1:3, but 3:5 or even greater than that it is that China threat.
I mean, if you look, to me it’s becoming clear that there is a mandate in China that there is going to be a China recovery, we want it to be China made as much as possible. Semis in general, I think are insulated from that at least in the near term, because either it’s entry, not a lot of local supplier. But if you think about the Chinese analog players, they are nipping at the heels of the low end, on the consumer side, guys like reached that you’ve competed with for many years. How do you handicap that threat, not only in the next one to three years but maybe over the next three, five or greater?
Rich Templeton

So, John, we spent time and I forget it was a year ago, two years ago. But we spent quite a bit of time really going through I think its 12th 6-year plan, we called out the 11th 6-year plan and really as a leadership team went down through what all the plans were, what all the intentions were.
And you can get some pretty good insight if you spend time studying that why the semiconductor industry or semiconductor companies can go operate with wholly owned subsidiaries in China because they don’t have alternatives and why things are different than other industries. So you can make sense of it on that front. Would they love to have a different outcome, you say to the answer correctly, it said yes we would. But they stated that five years ago they stated that in the 10th plan and that’s been stated for a while.
The other perspective that I add to that is the Taiwanese semiconductor industry has been trying to move in that direction for a long time. I say 20 years, because I can go back to the late 80s personally and know a lot of the companies that were starting up at that time. And I’m going to go to the word all, even though it’s kind strong, all continued to be very vertical, very big volume, most revenue per R&D dollar, working on the high-end personal electronics, smartphone, tablet, display whatever that is.
And I think we’re going to see and we continue to see the same trends even in some of the aspiring Chinese companies that are trying to stretch out. And it’s hard to tell what’s the Taiwanese company and a Chinese or an U.S. listed company for that matter. So we monitor them closely.
But you’ve really not watched any of them get to critical mass, and respect Richtek but they’ve gone very vertical as you know with those investments. And it’s probably the right thing for them to do because they don’t have a sales force, they don’t have breadth of portfolio. And I’m not sure if that time-horizon the things they’re going to try to go invest to make up.
So, we watch it, we have it on the list of things, as you can tell, we pay attention to. But to date you really haven’t seen the momentum go buy that.
John Pitzer – Credit Suisse

I’ll pull the audience one more time for a quick question upfront.

Hi Rich, I remember you buying the fab $0.10 a S$1, which is great. So, I’m curious how that some of these – your thoughts on sort of that the fab list thoughts and how you’re strategizing thinking about that adverse to peers?

In many ways it’s not a religious decision or a philosophical one, it’s just how can you do the best job when you’ve got 100,000 part types ship over 20 billion units a year, how do you bring the best service, the lowest cost and the best continuity of supply to all your customers.
And so, when we sit back and look at the manufacturing and technology, it’s really in some ways a foundational capability to be a leader in analog and embedded. And it’s actually one that if you look at our really very good traditional analog or micro-controller competitors, they’ll struggle as the world goes below 0.35 or 0.25 to where they’ll be putting more of their capacity on the outside. And so I think this will actually be a really fascinating asset that gets stronger over time.
I don’t see one of our analog competitors building a 300 millimeter wafer fab any day soon because they could house multiple bumpers of their company inside one of those fabs. Texas Instruments Inc. (NASDAQ:TXN) UBS Global Technology Conference November 19, 2013  3:30 PM ET
Executives
Dave Pahl - Director, Investor Relations

Steven Chin - UBS
Hi, good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for attending the next session here. My name is Steven Chin, and I'm one of the semiconductor analyst here at UBS. For this next session today, I have the pleasure of introducing Texas Instruments. And from TI we have Dave Pahl, who is the Director of Investor Relations. Dave is going to go through a couple or some prepared remarks, and then we'll have a Q&A session afterwards.
With that, I turn it over to Dave.
Dave Pahl
Thank you, Steven, for having us this afternoon. I thought I would start off with just giving an overview of TI and kind of where we are, and if you followed the company over the last five years or so, you know that we've been a company that has been transitioning and a transition that is essentially complete at this point in one, two markets, in analog and embedded processing. And this last quarter about 80% of our revenues were generated from those two segments.
And the reason we like analog and embedded processing is for a couple of reasons. The first is that they're both very large markets. The analog market is about $39 billion in size last year, embedded processing is about $17 billion, so combined just shy of $60 billion worth of market cap.
If you look at our position in each, we hold the number one position inside of analog. We've got that number one position and really only about 17% or 18% share in it, so lots of room for growth. In embedded processing, we've got a number two position, and there were about 14% share and again lots of room for growth.
The other thing that we like about those markets is they tend to be very fragmented and they're fragmented from a customer diversity standpoint. We service over a 100,000 customers. We've got a 100,000 products in our portfolio. So we service the very long tail of that.
And part of the reason why we have so many customers is that analog and embedded processing goes into like anything electronic. So it plugs into a wall or runs off of a battery, there is typically a product that we can sell that company and that provides a great opportunity for us.
The other thing is that both of those markets have a long track record of strong financial characteristics. So it has stable margins. There is, we like to think of it as, multiple modes of competitive barriers around those markets. So you don't see the major players moving or changing very much. It's a market where it's hard to enter into and market share doesn't move around a lot.
The other thing is that the products tend to last a long time. It can be decades or even multiple decades in some cases and you can manufacture those products on mature manufacturing equipment. And the net result of that part and part of the attractiveness of the financials is that generate lots of cash. And that's one of thing obviously we like about those markets.
So we think with that focus and now that that transition is complete, TI is in a unique position as a tech company to grow, generate and return cash to shareholders. If you look at our ability to grow and you look inside of the analog and embedded processing markets, those are markets that they're big enough, that they'll probably grow about the same rate as the semiconductor market.
More recently, we've had lots of debate of what that the rate of growth will be, it hasn't been very stellar certainly over the last five to seven years. Hard to describe the last five to seven years as normal with all the things that we've been through. But we generally believe that that those markets will grow somewhere around twice the rate of GDP. So it might be a little less, a little bit more, but somewhere in that area.
If you look at what we've done from a share gain standpoint, over the last four to five years we've gained about 30 basis points of share. In some years we've gained as much as 100 basis points, another year it's been at low as 10, but it's averaged about 30 basis points or so. So we've been able to gain share. And again, share doesn't move quickly in these markets and that's both a good thing and a bad sign. But because the markets are so good, just gaining 30 basis points of share will add a couple of points to our growth overall as an entity.
The other thing, if I move from grow and looked at our generation of cash, basically we believe we've built an engine that can generate between 20% and 25% of free cash flow off of every dollar that we generate and that's an average trailing 12 month number. If you looked at our last quarter, we just generated 24% of free cash flow. And free cash flow is defined as operating cash minus CapEx on that standpoint. So very strong generation of free cash flow.
And probably the most important part of that is we've committed through our capital management strategy to return a 100% of that free cash flow to investors in the form of dividends and buybacks. And when studying that dividend policy, we basically look at the average of the past four years' free cash flow, we take the 50% of that and that's what we targeted for dividend.
We've got a track record over the last 10 years of increasing our dividends. Each of the last 10 years, we just increased our dividend in October by 7% and I believe that was a 41% increase over the last year on an annualized basis. The remainder of that cash will buyback shares. If you look over the last 10 years, we've taken down our share count through those share repurchases by 36%. So a very meaningful reduction in shares overall. So again the commitment to return a 100% of free cash flow.
So now when we look forward, what we're focused on and spending our time doing is just completed this pretty significant transition in the last 5 years. So when we look forward over the next five years with a kind of envision where we want TI to be, and we see TI as a company focused on analog and embedded processing, and incrementally will increase our investments and industrial and automotive and focus those incremental investments in those markets.
So one of the things that we're doing is an example, and I like to describe the industrial market, that's long been defined electronics, what it's not. So it's not a consumer, it's not computing, it's not communication, it's not automotive, it's everything else. And we're going through a process of looking at over a dozen different sectors inside of our industrial.
And those sectors are things like medical or process control or building automation or motor control, those types of sub sectors, and we're looking at our investments across those to ensure that we're maximizing our opportunity to see how we're and where we're making our investment.
So that's what we're trying to do I think, and it was in a couple of minutes. And with that, maybe I'll take a seat and try to turn over to Steven.

And on an absolute level, our orders actually grew in the quarter by 1% that you were talking about. Book-to-bill is of course less than 1%. Dave Pahl
Yes, I think that a couple of ways to answer that question. The first is that we're trying to build a business that isn't tied to anyone end-market. And if I contrast to the company we were five and 10 years ago, we had over about a-third of our revenues in wireless. We had customer that represented 20% of our revenues in a couple of products, and that's lot of fun when things are growing and going up, it's not a lot of fun on the other side of that.
If you look at our company today, we don't have a customer that's more than mid single-digit percentage of our revenue and our top customer buys more than 800 products from us. And the largest devices is less than 1% of our revenue. So it just speaks to diversity of our revenue base. That's part of the reason why we like industrial and automotive. And that we actually do believe that there is in a secular trend and that will benefit us.

So that kind of shows up in systems like blind spot detection, that's getting more common in cars today. You are starting to see some cars that have collision avoidance with forward and backward radar systems.
You are starting to see some vision systems that will pickup collision avoidance, people walking in front of the car, lane detection, so if you begin to view it from the lane, you will get a hectic buzz on the steering wheel or it will actually steer you back into the lane. And then of course, you've seen parking assist in some cars and the ultimate of that of course is the driverless car, which there's lots of people working on that. There is lots of communications and interfaces that are necessary inside of a car today, both wireless and wired connections that were participating. And there is motors that are going from fluid-base motors to electric motors that need drivers and controllers and then the whole EV opportunity with battery management that plays well for our Wheelhouse.

So if someone wants a microcontroller, they're probably going to look at ST, they'll probably look at a microchip, they're also going to look at a TI. If they want to power product, they'll probably look at linear tech because they're also be searching at around the TI site. If they're looking at some type of signal chain products, the converter or an amplifier, then they'll look at ADI, but they will also be looking at that TI.
So we'll get early use into when customer start designs and our sales force is really focused on identifying, when a company actually starts a design, or call it a design kick off. And when that happens we pull basically experts from around the company, identify across the catalogue of are 100,000 devices, which few devices are going to make sense for that customer to evaluate to look at, and in some cases actually design parts of those sub-system for them, and when we do that, of course those are chock full of TI component as a starting point.
So it's ability to kind of look across the whole system and we're not just trying to design in the microcontroller or just trying to design in the converter or power chips, we're kind of looking across that, so we can just extract more content for design. How about in your microcontroller business, where you have both the MSCR picture for the [indiscernible] family and you have arm recortexed to the higher [indiscernible] kind of things. What does your market share look like there and why are you guys winning out and taking share there?

And it was an area that we weren't particularly strong, so we stepped up our OpEx investments several years ago to begin to build-out that catalogue of products and that's shown up inside of our EP segment from an operating margin standpoint.

And so this past quarter we delivered 54.8% gross margins, we had 54.5% I believe in third quarter of '10. Back in third quarter of '10 we had still a significant amount of legacy wireless revenue that we were shipping and this past quarter we were down to about 2% of our revenues were in that, so just the quality of that product has increased. Steven Chin - UBS
And going forward, the incremental gross margins on future sales growth, is 7% roughly the rate number to look at or do you think there is an opportunity to grow that even more, depending on which way the products sales mix shift between analog and embedded processing.
Dave Pahl
On incremental gross margins?
Steven Chin - UBS
Incremental.
Dave Pahl
So I think that when we looked at our past performance, we've looked at from a trough to a peak and looked over 15 years and just took the simple mathematical average of what happened to incremental margins, both in up and down market. That actually the mathematical average was exactly 75%. I don't think in any quarter inside of that 15-year period that we ever delivered 75%, but that was the average.
So we think that that's probably a pretty good place to start. In some of those quarters we had different product mixes that were going on and shifting around. It certainly didn't comprehend some of the shifts that we've had with the wireless products moving out as an example, so that would tend to help it.
The fact that we were able to buy a large portion of our manufacturing assets for pennies on the dollars and put that capacity in place allowing us to spend 4% of our revenues on CapEx and keeping that low using comprehended and those types of numbers either. So those things will benefit it over a cycle as you run, but I think 75% is probably good place to start, when they're doing the modeling.
Steven Chin - UBS
And just going back to an earlier point I brought up, which was the low inventory and also call it short lead time environment now out there, the reluctance of channels to build inventory and that said obviously requires faster response times from higher specialty results.
Dave Pahl
Right.
Steven Chin - UBS
Going forward if this type of behavior persist, is there anything that TI needs to do continue to better able to response this type of operating environment? And what kind of efficiency you think that might have for the overall business margins?
Dave Pahl
I think if you looked at structurally what's happen to our inventories and how we've set up our manufacturing is pretty significantly different from five and 10 years ago. We added a day of inventory, I think we finished last quarter at 106, up from 105, and we believe the right range to run the company is between 105 and 115 days overall. So we're at that lower-end of that range.
And one other thing that we're doing now that we weren't doing five years ago is we are intentionally building inventory of long-lived products that run in low volumes in periods of weaker demand. And we're doing that because, as an example, a piece of assembly test equipment it may take 30 minutes to set up that equipment, whereas you're going to run 10,000 parts or 1 million parts. And it may take let's say 30 minutes to run 10,000 that may be a year's worth of demand.
So why not run three years worth of demand and put it on the shelf. And you get all of that downtime kind of out of the way when you have weak demand. So when periods of stronger demand come, you spend that 30 minutes on something that's going to sit there and run for a day or two days. And so that has affected our inventory profile and we you do that on products that you've got confidence that you're going to sell for five or 10 years, where the risk of obsolescence is very low.
The second thing that has impacted our inventory profile is consignment and we've got 45% of our revenues on consignment, where we're actually holding on our balance sheet inventory sometimes rate on customer premise, we actually don't get an order or carry any backlog, but we've got electronic systems that feed our systems, tell us what demand looks like. And when they go to the cage and operate off of that demand and pull the days worth of inventory that they need, we then get the order at recognized revenue.
So our order book doesn't give us the visibility that used to in that past, but we've got this other system that provides us visibility. But because of that we're carrying more inventory overall than what we use to. But we view that as a good going, because we are controlling more of that inventory and we can match demand more closely to our customers need and that whole consignment inventories worked out better than I think we might have thought when we first entered into it.

And just from a competitive standpoint, I think there are a lot of competitors in that market that are coming up with SoC-type designs where in a lot of cases there is a DSP element that's integrated into a multicore processor. Dave Pahl
If you look at the most recent product category that we've launched, it's a architecture called KeyStone and if you tear apart and look at that architecture, you'll see that there are both ARM and DSP subsystems that's been inside of that as well as host of hardware accelerators. And the great thing with the KeyStone architecture is that it's scaleable and it can do a full LTE plus all of the fallbacks, necessary at the macro cell and you can run the same software all the way down to small cell.
And so it gives both our customers as well as operators confidence, eliminates the issues of coexistence and things like that, that others have had struggled with. So there we've had competitors that have had integrated solutions in the past. We don't know the market that exists without competitors, and there is alternate ways to do that solution. What kind of events or I guess changes in your overall financial model would we need to bump that up for opportunities for the further, maybe a more aggressive capital return strategy?
Dave Pahl
Well, I think 100% pretty aggressive overall. If you look over the last 10 years, I've talked about, we've had more of a steady hand and we've reduced our share count by 36%. So it's been a meaningful reduction in share count and for those that do like it, they view it as a very tax-efficient way to return capital to them. And the dividends kind of speak for themselves, so there is lots of advantages to the dividends as well.
Stephen Chin - UBS
And just touching upon the M&A strategy, talking about analog or National Semi that was your last big deal. Going forward, can you talk about what types of strategy or what other targets you might have in mind from an M&A standpoint?
Dave Pahl
So I'll start with the conclusion, which is a large acquisition unlikely, but I'll kind of backup and say what types of things will we look for and you really think about National it kind of fit, follow this criteria. One is we want a company that's products are centered up on the analog market, having a high exposure to industrial and automotive, that they have a large number of catalog products that have long lives, they have a diversity of customers that they shift those products to.
Those products are differentiated and therefore generate nice margins. They're able to manufacture among long-lived assets, so their CapEx remains low and they generate lots of cash, and then we want to be significantly under valued. And so there is lots of companies that kind of fit maybe those first criteria, but that last criteria is obviously a harder thing to match. And we look from a financial perspective, we look at multiple metrics, but one metric that we look at is can we exceed our cost of capital in a three to four year timeframe.
And two years in the National acquisition, we're very confident that we're going to be able to do that. But you look at our a lot these other properties that kind of fit that criteria. They're all pretty well-run enterprises. They generate lots of free cash flow. They've got strong balance sheet. A lot of them are run by either founders of near founders, so there is no for for-sale signs out front. And so the ability to step in and put a premium on top of that, you just can't make the numbers work.
Stephen Chin - UBS
And just probably one last question for me. From a competition standpoint, obviously there has been a lot of growth happening in Asia, and I think a lot of, call it, low cost analog manufacturers have spread it out that a couple of times.
Dave Pahl
Yes.
Stephen Chin - UBS
Do you see them much at all in any of your business segments? And also from a computing end-market standpoint, I think that's still a relatively healthy percentage of sales for TI. Do you see any pressure from that market because traditionally certain markets have seen an [indiscernible] in margin structure, and then some of your analog peers have migrated to other higher-value segments within analog. Kind of wonder, if you are seeing I think from a low-cost …
}
…migrated to other higher value segments within analog. Kind of wonder if you're seeing some low-cost, call it, Asia-peer standpoint?
Dave Pahl
So I think first, you wouldn't to be in our industry and ignore what's going on in Asia, you do it at your own peril. So it is something that we watch. We've seen multiple companies attempt to do to enter the market, probably the most successful, would be someone like a [ph] Ridgetech. And there they will find an end-market that's perhaps is closer to home and they'll appoint a development team at a very specific function. And so we'll typically go up against them more directly in our high volumes analog business.
They've got great designers and they've developed great parts. We have that too. They've got low cost structure. We've got a low cost structure. So we can compete pretty effectively against them. What you don't see is competitors investing in a broader catalog of products, kind of take five and 10 years to get into those markets. We really haven't seen any activity on that front.
Steven Chin - UBS
With that, I'd like to thank everyone for your attendance at the TI session today, and take care, Dave.
Dave Pahl
Thank you.

Good day, and welcome to the Texas Instruments Third Quarter 2013 Earnings Conference call. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mr. Ron Slaymaker. Please go ahead, sir.
Ron Slaymaker
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our third quarter earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's CFO, is with me today. For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our website at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the web.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the Safe Harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today, as well as TI's most recent SEC filings, for a more complete description.
Our mid-quarter update to our outlook is scheduled this quarter for December 9. At that time, we expect to adjust the revenue and earnings guidance ranges as appropriate.
This was a good quarter for TI. Revenue came in just above the midpoint of our guidance range, growing 6% sequentially and growing 10% if you exclude legacy wireless revenue, which declined to less than 2% of TI revenue in the quarter. Analog and Embedded Processing increased to 80% of TI revenue. The improved quality of our revenue is reflected in record gross margin in the quarter. Kevin will discuss this more in a few minutes.
Revenue growth in the quarter was supported by some of the vertical markets that were especially weak in the second quarter, including computing, game consoles and handset revenue outside of our legacy wireless revenue. Revenue from the communications infrastructure market continued to grow in the quarter. These areas were complemented by a continued strength in our automotive and industrial revenue.
From a year ago, revenue declined 4% due to the decrease in legacy wireless revenue. Excluding this revenue, we grew 3% from the year-ago quarter. On this basis, this was the first quarter of year-on-year growth since the third quarter of 2012. Again, excluding legacy wireless, we expect growth to accelerate to 8% in the fourth quarter at the middle of our guidance range.
The strength of our business model not only provides strong profitability, it also gives us confidence that we can sustainably generate $0.20 to $0.25 of free cash flow for every dollar of revenue. This metric is especially important to our shareholders as our capital management strategy is to return all of our free cash flow to them, except what is needed to repay debt. When measured over the trailing 12 months, free cash flow was 24% of revenue. Over that same period, we returned 133% of free cash flow to shareholders. In the third quarter alone, we returned $1 billion to shareholders through a combination of dividends and stock repurchases.
Earnings in the third quarter were above our expected range, a result of better-than-expected revenue and gross profit, tight operating expense control and some help from discrete tax items.
Let me walk through a few details of revenue. Analog revenue grew 11% sequentially. All 4 Analog product lines contributed to this growth, although Power Management was up the most, followed by High Volume Analog & Logic. These areas benefited from sequential growth across many markets, including those vertical markets that were impacted by inventory reductions in the second quarter.
Embedded Processing revenue grew 8% sequentially, with processors up the most, followed by growth in microcontrollers and connectivity. Processors were driven by applications processor sales into consumer and automotive applications and DSP sales into industrial applications. Microcontrollers were lifted mostly by sales of MSP430 products into industrial applications, as well as sales of microcontrollers into automotive safety applications.
In our Other segment, sequential growth in both product areas was offset by decline in legacy wireless. Legacy wireless revenue fell by $91 million to $57 million as we had expected. This decline was partially offset by growth in calculators and in custom ASIC revenue, which grew as a result of communications infrastructure. Royalties also grew, and DLP product revenue was about even.
Turning to distribution. Resales grew 9% sequentially. Distributors' inventory levels declined by about a day to just over 5 weeks.
Now Kevin will review profitability and our outlook.
Kevin P. March
Thanks, Ron, and good afternoon, everyone. This quarter, gross profit was $1.78 billion, up 13% sequentially. Gross margin was a record 54.8% of revenue and expanded 330 basis points sequentially. I think it is useful to compare this quarter's gross margin to that of the third quarter of 2010, wherein our last high-water mark for gross margin was set at 54.5%. In that earlier quarter, revenue was $3.74 billion, up -- 15% higher than our revenue this past quarter. Factory utilization in that earlier quarter was 8 points higher and our manufacturing capacity was lower since we have not yet brought online our cost-efficient, 300-millimeter analog wafer fab in Richardson, Texas or our yet to be acquired wafer fab in Chengdu, China. We were also still in the early stages of ramping our recently acquired Aizu Japan wafer fab. In addition, Analog and Embedded Processing were also much smaller then, contributing 60% of our revenue at that time.
The conclusion one can draw from this is that due to the structural changes that we've made at TI over the past few years, the quality of our revenue is much higher today. It is more diverse, more profitable and less capital intensive; and we remain better positioned to support future growth from a manufacturing capacity standpoint.
Continuing to operating expense. Combined R&D and SG&A expense of $833 million was reduced by $27 million sequentially. Acquisition charges were $86 million, unchanged from last quarter. Almost all of this amount is the ongoing amortization of intangibles, which is a noncash expense. The restructuring charges and other line of our income statement transitioned from a $282 million gain last quarter to a $16 million charge this quarter. As a reminder, last quarter's gain was due to the transfer of wireless connectivity technology to a customer. This quarter's charge is associated with the shutdown costs from the previously announced factory closings in Houston and Hiji, Japan.
Operating profit was $844 million or 26% of revenue. Our tax rate in the quarter was 23%, a point below our 24% annual effective tax due to discrete items that were included in the third quarter. Our annual effective tax rate is unchanged and 24% is the rate you should use in your models for the fourth quarter. Net income in the third quarter was $629 million or $0.56 per share, which includes $0.01 of discrete tax benefits.
Let me now comment on our capital management strategy, starting with cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $1.15 billion in the quarter. We increased our inventory by $6 million compared with the prior quarter. Inventory days increased by 1 day to 106 days, consistent with our model of 105 to 115 days. Capital expenditures were $124 million in the quarter and free cash flow was $1.03 billion.
On a trailing 12-month basis, cash flow from operations was $3.27 billion, about the same as a year ago. Trailing 12 months' capital expenditures were $402 million, down 27% from the year ago. As a result, free cash flow was $2.87 billion, up 4% from a year ago. Free cash flow was 24% of revenue for the trailing 12-month period, within our expected range of 20% to 25% of revenue. In the year-ago trailing 12 months period, free cash flow was 21% of revenue. Capital expenditures for the past 12 months were 3% of revenue. Our continued low capital spending level is a direct result of the strong capacity position that we have built with our strategic investments of the past few years. The cash flow that will result as we continue to fill up this capacity should be stronger in the years ahead.
I'll note that depreciation expense for the past 12 months exceeded our capital expenditures by $496 million. As a percent of revenue, depreciation was more than 400 basis points higher than our capital expenditures. This is one of the reasons why our free cash flow has been trending higher than our net income. Of course, as depreciation declines at the rate of capital spending over the next few years, gross margin will benefit. Another reason why free cash flow has trended higher than net income is the noncash amortization expense of $80 million to $85 million per quarter, that will remain on our income statement for another 6 years. For the past 12 months, amortization expense was $339 million or about 3% of revenue.
And as we've said, strong cash flow, particularly cash flow -- free cash flow, means that we can continue to provide significant cash returns to our shareholders. In the third quarter, TI paid $308 million in dividends and repurchased $734 million of our stock. Our capital management strategy is to return all of our free cash flow to shareholders, except for what we need to repay debt. In the last year, we reduced our debt level by $500 million. Free cash flow was $2.87 billion and we returned a total of $3.82 billion to shareholders or 133% of free cash flow. We've been able to return more than our free cash flow because proceeds from exercises of employee stock options, totaling $1.28 billion over the past 12 months, have also been an additional source of cash for the company. To break out the cash return, in the past 12 months, we repurchased $2.7 billion of our stock or 95% of free cash flow. Similarly, we paid $1.08 billion in dividends or 38% of our free cash flow.
Fundamental to our cash return strategy and our cash management and our tax practices, we ended the third quarter with $3.59 billion of cash and short-term investments, with 82% of that amount owned by TI's U.S. entities. Because our cash is largely onshore, it's readily available for a variety of uses, including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock. TI orders were about even sequentially and our book-to-bill ratio was 0.97, consistent with seasonal declines in the fourth quarter.
We expect TI revenue in the range of $2.86 billion to $3.10 billion in the fourth quarter. At the middle of this range, revenue would decline 8% sequentially, with about half of that decline coming from the seasonal drop in calculators. The remainder of the decline is consistent with the semiconductor industry's pattern over the past 3 years: 2010, 2011 and 2012, as well as our own history over that same period when legacy wireless revenue is excluded. In the fourth quarter, legacy wireless products should decline to about $50 million. We continue to expect that revenue from these products will essentially be gone as we enter next year. We expect earnings per share to be in the range of $0.42 to $0.50.
In summary, we believe the third quarter provides a preview of what TI is capable of producing as a company focused on Analog and Embedded Processing. The improved quality of our revenue is evident from the higher gross margin and free cash flow generation compared with our past. We also believe our top line performance and potential will become more evident without the steady headwind of declining wireless revenue in the past few years. Our manufacturing capacity position remains strong and we have a good opportunity for continued growth, while maintaining our capital expenditures at lower levels in the years ahead.
With that, let me turn it back to Ron.
Ron Slaymaker
Thanks, Kevin. Operator, you can now open the lines up for questions. [Operator Instructions] Operator?

And based upon the guidance that we're hearing from some of the other competitors, ourselves included, it looks like we're stepping up for our fourth quarter of -- a fourth year of 4Q declines. In fact, if you take a look at TI and extract out the wireless revenue, you'll see that our revenues have gone down in the fourth quarter of each of those same years, similar to the industry. Okay, Vivek, the 24% effective tax rate is what you should use for the fourth quarter. With the various things occurring during the year, the entire year will be a little bit different than that. But for planning purposes, use 24% for the fourth quarter. I would remind you that, that tax rate includes the R&D tax credit, which is set to expire at the end of this year. And it's unclear whether or not that will be renewed by congress in a timely fashion as we get into 2014. For us, that provides about a 2% benefit to our taxes. So absent that R&D tax credit, we'd be closer to a 26% tax rate as opposed to the 24% that we're suggesting that you use for fourth quarter. As it relates to buybacks, I would just mention that, again, the reason it's been as strong as it has been, the buybacks and dividends at 133% of our free cash flow, is a function of not only improving free cash flow, which we certainly have seen, but also the benefit the company receives when employees exercise their non-qual stock options. And given the increase in the -- in stock prices this past year for our company, we've seen an increase in employee stock option exercises. Just to give you a few numbers and summarize that to kind of recharacterize what I mentioned in my prepared remarks, our free cash flow for the last 12 months was $2.87 billion. Proceeds from employee stock options was $1.28 billion. So that means we had sources of cash over the last 12 months of $4.15 billion. We used or returned to shareholders, in the form of dividends and buybacks, $3.82 billion. Then we paid off debt earlier this year of $500 million. So we've used a total of $4.32 billion. So we've virtually used all that we have generated this past year. And we do that because one of the things we mentioned our capital management strategy is that we have a model for how much cash that we carry. And to the extent that we generate cash beyond that model level, we're quite comfortable with returning that to shareholders, as we have been doing. As to the ability of that to continue to run at those high levels, that's a really hard call. I would say that stock options do expire over time, and these are generally 10-year stock option grants that are granted to employees. So quite a few of these options are quite old, and they get used up. Ron Slaymaker

Our footprint on a global basis, including the benefit that we got with the National acquisition, is allowing us to have a relatively effective current tax rate and further enabling us a pretty high repatriation of cash, which, as you know, [indiscernible] of our cash home and we just ended this past quarter with 82% of our cash onshore. But for planning purposes, as we look into the future, we assume that the U.S. tax rate stays about the same incrementally at 35%, and we just model that on a go-forward basis from a repat standpoint. Another important point to keep in mind is that depreciation today is running about 400 basis points ahead of capital expenditures.
